TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator McMullan will be absent from question time today as he is still on his way back from the APEC ministerial meeting. He could not get on the flight that I had, which gave him the dubious pleasure of coming back overnight. In his absence, I will answer questions relating to trade; Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services; and Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans. What did the minister mean at the weekend when he said he `spoke too strongly in the present tense' when he accused Thailand of providing support and sanctuary to Khmer Rouge soldiers? How could such a mistake have been made? Is he again blaming the officers of his department? Will he tell the Senate what effect his mistake will have on our relations with Thailand, what influence it will have at the APEC meeting and what effect it will have on trade relations with Thailand in particular?

—The situation is simply this: in a spirit, I suppose, of conciliation which we were trying to get at in resolving this issue as between the two of us, the foreign minister and I had a long talk about the whole subject of cross-border activity by the Khmer Rouge. It was certainly the longest, frankest, most productive and, I think, most encouraging talk I have had on that subject—and I have had many of them over the years—with representatives of the Thai government.

PARA.TAB: The situation essentially is this: if we look back at the history of this, during the period of the Vietnamese occupancy of Cambodia from 1978 to 1989 there was unequivocal and openly acknowledged Thai government and military support for the Khmer Rouge, as indeed there was for other elements of the anti-Hun Sen government resistance. Following the installation of the Chatichai government in 1989 and the withdrawal of the Vietnamese, that support took a less overt military form but was more than amply compensated by a huge amount of business activity, not least so far as the logging and gem industries were concerned, with results with which we are all too unhappily familiar.

When the Chuan government came into office in 1992, and in the context of the UN operation—by that stage, of course, in full swing—there was a stated determination on the part of the Chuan government to sever those linkages which had traditionally existed, and a number of steps were taken, including consolidation of bans on arms trades, on logs, on gems, and a stated intention to be more effective in limiting that access.

The problem was that for a very long period, despite the excellent intentions of the Chuan government, it has to be said, there were many elements within Thailand that were still offering forms of assistance, nowhere more conspicuously so as recently as just a few months ago, in April-May this year, when—in the context of the abortive Cambodian military operations at Pailin and Anlong Veng—overt support of a major kind was given to Khmer Rouge forces, enabling them to regroup and remount an assault.

There were other bits and pieces of evidence around, not all of which can be readily disclosed on the public record, which suggested that certainly as recently as four or five months ago this sort of support was occurring. I probably did not give sufficient weight—and I acknowledge this, as I did in the light of my discussion with Minister Thaksin—to the new determination which came over Thai policy really from June and particularly from July this year at the time the Cambodian government actually formally outlawed the Khmer Rouge. That gave the Thai government a new piece of weaponry in dealing with difficult elements in its own system. It has been much more forthcoming in terms of its activity now on the border. And Minister Thaksin, as one element in our conversation, announced after my discussion that he would escort or make available access by our ambassadors and other representatives from interested missions to go down there on the border now, which is something which has not previously happened, and see for themselves the scope and scale of the activity now being mounted to try to deal with this sort of border activity.

I was given a number of other assurances relating to movement of personnel as well as movement of goods and money and, generally speaking, it was a very satisfactory conversation—certainly, as I began by saying, the best I have had on this subject and really quite encouraging. Under those circumstances and in order to help defuse what had become a difficult problem in bilateral terms and in domestic-political terms in Thailand, I was ready and willing to concede the point that perhaps I had been a little unfair in speaking as much as I did in the present tense given the changes that have occurred, manifestly, since July.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for the history lesson. But, really, we are interested in the basis upon which he made statements last week that were highly critical of Thailand, and his need, to the embarrassment of Australia—which is what is of concern—to withdraw those statements, acknowledging that perhaps he had spoken too strongly. What is the factual situation then, particularly when out of the country the minister said he could not give the sources of his information because it was intelligence-based? Now, apparently, he is saying he was out of touch. What exactly is the level of support being given by Thai military personnel to the Khmer Rouge? What does the minister now think will be the consequence of his mistake—a mistake he has had to acknowledge—bearing in mind what we heard this morning about possibilities of effects on trade?

—I do not accept the characterisation of what I said as a mistake. There has been a longstanding series of expressions of concern by many governments, many public spokesmen—including, I think, Senator Hill himself on numerous occasions—about the state of play and the porosity of the Thai border. And there are some continuing grounds for concern, certainly so far as some continuing business activity is concerned. But I am satisfied that a really major effort is now being made by the Thai government with appropriate enforcement mechanisms in place and I believe that there is a reasonable chance that we will not get a repetition, at least on the scale that has occurred in the past, of this sort of activity.

PARA.TAB: I am asked to give further information about the nature of the regimes in place. One of the matters that I specifically raised was the question of free movement of Khmer Rouge leadership, which has been an unhappy characteristic of this relationship in the past. The truth of the matter is that the Thais have made clear that is not going to occur in the future.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and relates to his responsibilities for the Australian Antarctic Territory. Can the minister outline the principal outcomes from the 13th annual meeting of the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources held in Hobart last week? What role did Australia play in achieving these outcomes?

—The purpose of the commission is to implement the objective of the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources while allowing for the rational use of those particular resources. In previous commission meetings, Australia has been a significant conservation influence. This role was very successfully continued at this year's meeting on a wide range of subjects and, I might say, sometimes under very difficult circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Australia was very active at the meeting and achieved some notable successes, which I would like to outline to the Senate. Australia played a leading role in suggesting ways to mitigate the incidental mortality of sea birds from fishing and took a strong stand on the need for major reductions in such mortality. This had a major effect on the design of conservation measures adopted by the commission for several fisheries and established precedence relevant to other fisheries forums.

An Australian proposal to improve the procedure for notifying commission members of the results of inspections of fishing vessels, including any alleged infractions of commission conservation measures being committed, was accepted. This will greatly improve the speed with which members are given this information and allow earlier consideration of any ramifications of the alleged infractions and the need for further actions.

Australia has submitted and gained acceptance for fisheries research data, gathered over three years, for the commission area that includes the Australian territory of Heard Island and the McDonald Islands. This is the first time that a party to the convention has produced the research data necessary for fisheries management before a fishery has commenced and our approach, I might say, was widely applauded. A proposal submitted by Australia seeking to increase the transparency of the procedure used to invite all types of observers—intergovernmental, non-governmental and state—was adopted by the commission. Australia also sought an end to the opposition by some commission members to environmental NGO participation at all commission forums and the placing of restrictions on those NGOs. Unconditional access was secured for environmental NGOs to the commission's scientific committee.

Australia also secured improved compliance with fisheries management measures. Australia made a presentation on the use of satellite transponders on fishing vessels to allow checking of vessels' positions from a land based monitoring centre, thus improving compliance with management measures. The commission has agreed in principle to the use of such a monitoring system in future in some fisheries, and a design of systems similar to those used in Australia will be submitted for consideration at the next meeting.

Important advances were also made in the development of assessment methods which take uncertainty into account in determining precautionary catch limits for fish and krill. These advances also resulted from work done by Australian scientists. I think these outcomes of the meeting are significant achievements for environmental protection in all of Antarctica and are further proof of Australia's effectiveness in working within international forums in protection of the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The Prime Minister has consistently stressed the urgent need for a national electricity grid in order to get competitive power prices to businesses around the country. Last Thursday the minister poured cold water on the grid proposal and claimed that `lower electricity prices could well result in greater energy consumption'. Were these remarks simply driven by the minister's insatiable appetite for personal grandstanding and a desperate need to pander to environmental extremists, irrespective of the consequences for business, or did the minister's remarks have the endorsement of the Prime Minister and cabinet? Does the minister support a national electricity grid and cheaper electricity prices for Australian industry?

—In a wide ranging speech that I made to the Electrical Supply Association of Australia, one sentence of which I think Senator Alston tried to communicate in his question, I mentioned that, of course, there can be an environmental impact of lower electricity prices. It goes, as most intelligent human beings would understand, to the question of consumption levels. Mr President, in Australia we are high energy consumers, as you would know. The point that I made is that at times this can have an environmental consequence. That would be clear—

—It was a speech very well received by Australian business, as Senator Alston knows. It is proper to point out possible consequences for higher energy consumption, which goes, of course, to issues like the level of greenhouse gas emissions in this country. I believe the speech that I made would have strong support broadly within government, and I certainly stand by the remarks I made.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I noticed that the minister said that it was a very well received speech. Does he mean by the particular audience which he was addressing or does he mean by the wider business community? Does he stand by that one sentence, which he obviously hoped would not be picked up by the wider community, or is the truth of the matter that his government has lost any stomach for micro-economic reform, has thrown in the towel on Hilmer and is now interested only in pandering to sectional interest groups, irrespective of the consequences for the Australian economy?

—The thrust of my speech was this: as we move to reform in the electricity supply sector, as we move to micro-economic reform, we do have to take account of possible environmental impacts and consequences of those particular actions.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on the issue of relevance. The question was very clear and specific: does Senator Faulkner support a national grid and does he support cheaper prices? Yes or no?
—There is no point of order; you full well know it.

—I was saying that as we move to a national grid, as we move to continue our micro-economic reform agenda in the electricity sector, there will remain a need for us to consider the environmental consequences of those actions. I think the views were generally embraced, and I will continue to raise those issues with interested parties. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware of remarks recently made by Senator O'Chee regarding the young homeless allowance? Is there any basis for the allegations he has made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am delighted that you have reminded us of former Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen's presence here today. It is just what the National Party needs—and certainly Senator O'Chee. If we read what Senator O'Chee has been saying, he has gone off the hook since Senator Bjelke-Petersen left. It is a terrible shame. Senator O'Chee has been running around North Queensland frightening families by giving very false information about the young homeless allowance. He has been whipping up unnecessary concern in a very irresponsible manner. I quote from the Tablelands Advertiser of 2 November—and there are other papers which contain similar quotes:

ANSWER.PARA: Families in the far north are being split apart by payments from the Federal Government which encourage youths, often as young as 14, to leave home.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly.
—That is what Senator O'Chee says; it is wrong and he knows it is wrong, as I am about to tell him. That is why we should get Senator Bjelke-Petersen back.
—You come and meet the parents.

—Senator O'Chee might listen: the truth is that across the whole of Australia the young homeless allowance is paid to only 300 young people under the age of 15, and 1,400 aged 15 receive the payment. I put that in for the sake of completion.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee ignores the tragic reality that, while the great majority of parents fulfil their obligations, there are some cases of children and young people coming from places where they are physically or sexually abused. Senator O'Chee told the Townsville Bulletin that the young homeless allowance was splitting families in the small town of Ravenshoe and said, `In the past year I have realised the problem is getting worse.' The Senate will be interested to hear that the number of recipients of the young homeless allowance in that town has rocketed in the past year from zero to one! I do not know how Senator O'Chee can make a case on those sorts of figures.

I can assure Australian families that, contrary to the very misleading and, I think, damaging remarks by Senator O'Chee, exactly the opposite is happening: children cannot walk into Social Security and pick up the young homeless allowance. The facts are that, before any payment of the allowance can be made, the claim must be verified. In a majority of cases, this means that parents are contacted. Where this is inappropriate because of the nature of the child's problems, the claims must still be verified, often with teachers, child protection officers, family, clergy or the like.

Also, under protocol arrangements in place with the states, the Department of Social Security refers state wards and young people who are homeless or at risk to the relevant state or territory department for an assessment of their circumstances and determination of the appropriate care and support arrangements. Parents are also able to provide information to the department at any time. This information must be taken into account when deciding whether to pay or continue to pay the allowance.

If those opposite want to be taken seriously, I think it is important that they tell the facts about the young homeless allowance, not their preferred version of scaremongering and anxiety. If Senator O'Chee knows any examples that are contrary to that, he should let me or Mr Baldwin and the department know. But what Senator O'Chee has said is absolutely wrong. It is mischievous and only creates anxiety in the community.

It was essentially of an ethnic character, triggered by an incident in which an East Timorese man was killed by a trader from elsewhere in Indonesia, from Sulawesi, and that generated an explosive reaction from East Timorese locals. A number of civilians and businesses were subsequently attacked and it did turn into a fairly substantial riot, but not on the scale that was originally reported of 1,000 or more people being involved. The figure was, we were subsequently told, rather less than that—not much more than about 100 people being actively involved in the riot.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the number of deaths, the only confirmed report that we have had is of the death of the original East Timorese person who was killed by the Sulawesi in the local dispute that triggered the whole thing off. —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to his recent meeting with the Indonesian foreign affairs minister, Mr Ali Alitas, prior to the APEC meetings in Indonesia, and particularly to discussions at that meeting concerning `special status' for East Timor. I ask: given that Bishop Belo has stated that the East Timorese people will support `special status' only if it is a step towards self-determination, does the minister agree that `special status' should be seen as the first step for self-determination for East Timor, or is this just a cosmetic attempt to deal with the issue of East Timor and reduce international criticism?

—Bishop Belo is a very important figure in East Timor and his views certainly ought to be taken very seriously, but they do not necessarily represent the be all and end all and do not necessarily represent a practically workable solution. For example, Bishop Belo has recently gone on record as opposing the establishment of an Australian consulate in Dili, yet we have been asked on innumerable occasions by East Timorese representatives in Australia and many other members of the NGO community to press for that as an important and helpful step forward. So there are questions of judgment involved in this and I think we just have to pick our way through that rather than assuming that the words of any one leader or senior figure are necessarily decisive.

PARA.TAB: The self-determination that Australia talks about and wants to encourage is self-determination within the framework of Indonesian sovereignty. That is the implication of de jure recognition which the other side of Australian politics initiated in 1979 and which we subsequently endorsed when we came into office.

Self-determination in that context, and in the way in which that expression is being used a lot internationally these days, does mean genuine respect for different ethnicity and genuine respect for human rights claims of particular groups within larger national or state entities. That is the kind of thing we are talking about. In that context, some kind of special political autonomy or special status—of the kind, for example, that exists in Jogjakarta or Aceh—might be thought to be helpful in that larger process of reconciliation. It is not by itself enough to solve the whole problem but it is at least part of the answer. The other elements of the answer are those I have described, in particular the military drawdown as well as other measures being taken to respect local, religious and cultural sensitivities to a greater extent than has been the case so far.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister mentioned, Aceh apparently has special status. I point out that, during the last year, as many people were killed there as in East Timor. Does the minister feel that the granting of special status will assist in eliminating or reducing the killings, tortures and human rights abuses—I know he mentioned the military drawdown as well—in East Timor? Is Australia's accepting of a largely cosmetic change just a way for Indonesia and Australia to manage the issue, so that they can get on with trade negotiations?

—I do not suggest that it is a sufficient condition but it may be a necessary condition. It would certainly be a helpful condition in establishing a rather different atmosphere, a rather different climate and a rather different set of thought processes in terms of the way the Indonesian government and senior military personnel regard the situation in East Timor. I am perfectly well aware that Aceh has been an occasion for a lot of unhappiness and human rights abuse in its own terms, not so much recently in the last year but certainly for some time before that. Nobody suggests that there are any solutions to this which are simple.

PARA.TAB: But Australia's motivation in this is not as Senator Margetts describes. We are, and always have been, absolutely sincere in our endeavours to do the best we possibly can for the East Timorese people. We believe the best way of doing that is within the context of a broad-based, multi-dimensional relationship in which what we say is taken seriously and not just dismissed as howls of outrage from those who are ignorant and not being especially helpful.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The latest Access Economics budget monitor warns there is likely to be a hole of $2.1 billion in the government's budget deficit forecast for 1997-98. Will the minister now concede that the government's budget reduction strategy has always been based on false and misleading assumptions? Will he also concede that the Australian people will continue to pay the price for this dishonesty in the form of continuing high interest rates? How does the government propose to cover the $2.1 billion shortfall without a further hike in indirect taxes or increases in income taxes?

—I read the Australian Financial Review report of the Access Economics analysis. Apparently Senator Gibson has not read the closing paragraphs of this report, which say that Access Economics came to a prediction for economic growth in the out years of this current budget which is below that of the budget itself and, might I say, looking at the whole level of private sector predictions for budget growth, below that of what the private sector analysts would have as being the out years of budget growth. The reason that Access Economics has come to the conclusion that it does is, in my view, that it has underestimated the growth and strength in the Australian economy. As a consequence, it has come to a hole in the budget that does not exist. It has done that for the out years.

PARA.TAB: The economy at the present time is growing strongly. Budget predictions were for a 4.3 per cent growth over this budgetary year. Private sector analysts now have the level of economic growth up around 5.5 per cent. There is nothing on the screen that would cause us in government to review—certainly not to review downwards—the level of economic growth that we expect for the out years in the budget. Therefore, we do not accept that the illusory hole, predicted to exist based on the estimates that Access Economics has come up with—which appear to be unsupported by other forecasting agencies—exists. As a consequence of not accepting its view of economic life, nor do we accept the implication in the question that Senator Gibson has put—that there is a bigger hole that we will somehow be struggling to fill.

The projections for the 1994 budget estimated the deficit for 1996-97 at O.9 per cent of GDP, with the budget to approach balance by 1997-98. This would be achieved by expenditure restraint in non-priority areas, causing outlays to fall as a percentage of GDP over the forward estimates periods; lower unemployment, reducing pressure on social security outlays; and projected growth in taxation revenue of 7.4 per cent in real terms in 1994-95 and 6.9 per cent in 1995-96, largely due to being driven up by higher growth in the economy.

As I have said, Access Economics has forecast higher deficits in the out years, lower economic growth than forecast by the government at budget time, and higher public debt interest costs as a result of higher interest rates. Post-budget developments do not suggest that the deficit projections announced in the 1994-95 budget need to be revised upwards. Higher interest rates will certainly increase public debt interest costs, but faster employment growth since the budget will result in a lower than forecast expenditure on unemployment benefits.

The growth forecasts for 1994-95 and later years which appear in the budget remain on track. GDP was forecast to grow by 4 1/2 per cent in 1994-95, slowing to a growth rate of 4 1/4 per cent in 1995-96 and four per cent in 1996-97 and 1997-98. While the composition of growth in the 1994-95 period is likely to differ from that of the forecast at budget time, with a weaker farm sector and a stronger non-farm sector, overall developments since the budget suggest that the 4 1/2 per cent figure is achievable. As a consequence, it is interesting to see what Access Economics has written, but the government does not accept its viewpoint.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. There is little doubt that economic growth is strong and is continuing, with solid gains in production, sales, productivity, exports and, importantly, jobs across the board. While this must be welcomed, except by the negative people opposite, it has been evident in the past that many small to medium size firms are constrained during periods of growth by lack of patient development capital to fund their growth, yet the performance of these small but potentially high growth firms is crucial to the strength and sustainability of economic growth. Can the minister assure the Senate that the right policy settings are in place to encourage financial markets to direct capital to this vital part of the business sector?
—I am very pleased to see former Senator Bjelke-Petersen in the gallery. If she were in the coalition now, she would certainly be a candidate for leadership.

PARA.TAB: The government is always looking for opportunities to improve the economic settings. One of the key drivers of economic growth is the availability of capital, and within that broad ambit is the availability of patient capital—patient capital for small to medium size businesses; patient capital that can be invested over a long period and where there may be a high risk but the potential of high return on that investment.

One of the approaches the government has adopted from a public policy point of view to improve the availability of patient capital for small to medium size businesses was set out in the One Nation statement in 1992, and that is for the establishment of pool development funds—funds which provide a lower tax level than otherwise obtains, but for money raised from the private sector for on-lending to small to medium size businesses. In the Working Nation white paper this year we reduced the tax level on pool development funds from 25 per cent to 15 per cent in order to attract more private sector funding to small to medium size businesses in Australia and to provide a decent pool of patient capital for that sector of the economy.

Since we announced those changes, the number of pool development funds has almost doubled, from 10 to 19, and the amount of extra capital attracted into the economy to the end of June 1994—a very short time horizon between announcement and outcome in this case—was $35 million. We raised an extra $35 million for investment in small to medium size companies. But importantly, by the end of this year, pool development funds expect to raise $140 million in patient capital, the capital for small to medium size enterprises which will be in the market as a result of the settings we have now put into place for pool development funds.

I understand that existing pool development funds are planning to raise up to $340 million—that is, an extra $340 million—in the longer term. By any measure this is a valuable contribution to the pool of capital available for the small to medium size companies which are, of course, the main engine of economic growth and future employment prospects for most Australians.

The PDF is a flexible investment vehicle, and a number of PDFs have been set up to target specific industry sectors—something which I am sure will interest Senator Spindler—and to serve areas in regional Australia targeting the particular needs of those regions. For instance, last week John Fairfax Holdings announced that it was investing $6 million in a pool development fund—AusAsean Multimedia Capital Ltd—which came onto the market a couple of months ago to raise capital specifically for the multimedia industry.

I know that AusAsean Multimedia Capital Ltd is encouraged by the interest and support for its capital raising and expects to be in a position to earmark its first investment in this emerging industry sector within the next six to eight weeks. As I have said, others are targeting developments in regional Australia. I think the pool development funds are showing their worth to the economy by attracting funding at lower tax levels for small to medium size companies' growth.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the sentence of 12 months imprisonment handed down yesterday in the United Arab Emirates in relation to an Australian citizen, Mr Robert Bowra, as a result of a maritime accident which occurred on 5 August this year. I remind the minister of the fact that Mr Bowra has been in custody since 5 August this year despite a court order for his release. I also refer the minister to the fact that the sentence was handed down in Mr Bowra's absence. My question is: can the minister assure the Senate that Mr Bowra has been properly dealt with according to the laws of the United Arab Emirates, and can the minister further advise the Senate what steps have been taken by the government to ensure that Mr Bowra has been treated fairly?

—I do not yet have complete information on the particular charges for which Mr Bowra was convicted. He was charged with causing the death of a victim, an equivalent charge to manslaughter, and causing injury to a third party. As Senator Ellison has said, he was sentenced to 12 months imprisonment. With three months already served, the expected release date is August next year. There is still a question of financial compensation to the family of the deceased to be resolved.

PARA.TAB: We have taken up the question as to whether Mr Bowra was properly dealt with in terms of the legal process of the United Arab Emirates in the context of the bail order which was apparently made. Some representations have been made, but I am not in a position to give Senator Ellison the results of those representations and the nature of the response from the UAE. We have not received that yet.

We have been told—this is by the official authorities; it may have no formal status yet—that the charges to be laid would take account of the gentleman in question not taking the injured person to hospital, leaving the scene of the accident, attempting to leave the country, and denying knowledge of the incident when apprehended at the airport. So there may be some other dimensions to this which have not been brought out into the public domain. All these things will need to be taken into account in any balanced assessment of how the matter has been handled.

Our consular people have been closely monitoring this situation and giving the usual appropriate consular support. The general impression that has been conveyed to me is that the treatment given to Mr Bowra has not been evidently different from that which is normally given to either expatriates or locals in these situations. But there is a big question mark, certainly, about this bail order matter. When I have some further information that pulls all these threads together in a more conclusive way, I will be happy to share it with Senator Ellison and, if he wants, with the Senate as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask for the minister's personal assurance that he will take whatever steps are necessary to rectify the situation should it come to light that Mr Bowra has been treated unfairly. In that regard, I refer to the fact that he did not have the ability to cross-examine witnesses and had limited ability to call witnesses in relation to his defence.

—In lots of countries we are faced with the situation that the legal processes do not work in the way in which ours does. The most that we can realistically do in these situations is to ensure that no differential treatment is being meted out to the particular individual concerned—certainly as compared with locals in similar circumstances. Whether one then wants to think it appropriate to make representations on the larger issues of principle that are involved in the operation of the justice process is another question, but there is a limited amount we can do for individuals in these situations.
—Foreign ministers are supposed to stand up for their citizens overseas.

—Someone else deserves an interjection, over there in the front row, Mr President. The circumstances of this case require some further attention in the way that I described. I will do my best to give Senator Ellison a further answer as soon as all the relevant information comes to hand.

—I said that I will refer the question to the minister, and I will.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. —The submission will go to cabinet and an announcement will then be made later this month. I do not know the exact date of the status of the GATT bills, but I assume it would be in the same time frame as the GATT bills coming into the Senate. —My question is directed to Senator Schacht, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I understand that the minister recently attended an APEC meeting in Japan for ministers responsible for small and medium size enterprises. I notice from the press reports following the meeting that one of the outcomes of the conference was a decision to hold the next meeting in Australia. What benefit is there for Australia in hosting this conference and, also, what benefit can be gained for Australian small and medium size businesses by being involved in this forum?

—In mid-October I attended the first APEC meeting of ministers for small and medium size enterprises in Osaka, a meeting hosted by the Japanese government. The meeting took place as a result of a decision of the APEC leaders meeting held in Seattle last year.

PARA.TAB: In the discussions that took place, and as a result of those discussions, the suggestion from Australia that we host the next meeting was unanimously accepted by all member countries of APEC. This will be the first fully fledged meeting of APEC ministers in Australia since one of the original meetings was held here three years ago. I think the fact that we were able to secure the next ministerial meeting recognises that Australia is at the forefront of innovative policies for small and medium size enterprises.

I pay tribute to the success of the organisation involved in the meeting and the agenda prepared by our Japanese hosts. From the discussions that took place amongst ministers, it can be said that most of the issues raised by small and medium size enterprises in Australia are similar to those in most of the member countries of APEC—issues dealing with the availability of finance for small business, technology transfer, the introduction of best practice, and, above all else, the desire of all countries to encourage their SMEs to become export oriented wherever possible.

One of the major issues discussed—and the Australian delegation took a major role in this—related to how we can establish networking arrangements between SMEs across a number of countries to boost the access of those SMEs to markets so as to improve their economic prospects.

The other feature of the conference that we will certainly want to build on next year in Australia when we host the conference relates to several sessions when representatives of small and medium size enterprises from the various APEC countries participated in direct discussion with ministers in an open forum to exchange ideas. This proved very successful. For the conference here next year we are looking at arranging for a greater representation of practising SMEs to hold meetings, to hold discussions, to build up their own networks amongst APEC countries and, as well, to have the interaction with ministers about what are the issues for SMEs within the APEC region.

I certainly want to pay tribute here to the contribution of the Australian private sector. Various industry organisations in Australia, such as the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, were represented. They all made a significant contribution, and it is one reason that fellow APEC members recognised that Australia is the appropriate place to hold the next conference. I look forward to being involved in the hosting of that conference next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to an answer the minister gave in the Senate on 30 August when questioned on Labor's jobs for the boys program. In defence he said, `Let me respond with some of the other appointments we have made during this tenure of government: Warwick Smith as telecommunications ombudsman'—for one. As the ombudsman for telecommunications is not selected by government, not appointed by government and not paid by government, was the minister just ignorant of the facts or did he just mislead the Senate to cover the 50-odd jobs for the boys that this government has put in place?

—It is perfectly true he was not appointed by the government as such, in the sense of it being a cabinet appointment, any more than Sallyanne Atkinson was appointed by the government as such. She was appointed by Austrade to do the job that she is now doing in Paris. But the point simply being made in relation to those appointments is that there is no element of adverse treatment, discrimination or perceived worry on the part of any of these organisations that the person they appoint might be ineffective by virtue of his or her political credentials. They have total confidence in this government's willingness to treat people absolutely on their merits. That is what we have been prepared to do; that is what we will continue to do.

PARA.TAB: If, when in government back in the 1970s, the opposition had had any decency at all and had treated Gough Whitlam on his merits and appointed him to the International Court of Justice instead of treating him like a pariah, if the opposition had had the decency to do with someone like Whitlam what we did with Malcolm Fraser when we fully supported his appointment as Secretary-General of the Commonwealth—I spent a good many months in fact campaigning for him—if the opposition had had the decency to establish some precedents in this respect, it would have a lot more credibility than it obviously does now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I can see by the minister's answer that he has been fully caught out, so I ask: if the minister does not want to go down in this Senate as a `Richo', in other words, a self-confessed liar, will he put the record straight that he did mislead the Senate?
—Order! I would ask you to withdraw the imputation of lying.
—Mr President, I did not call the minister a liar. I said that Richo was a self-confessed liar. I do not think that that is unparliamentary.
—Sorry, I misheard it.

—I have nothing much to add in this respect. I was making the point generally about government appointments, appointments to government instrumentalities, with appropriate respect being given for people who deserve respect. If the opposition had approached that sort of issue with a little more of that kind of spirit, a little bit more of that kind of conviction, and a little bit more of that kind of decency in the past, it would be a hell of a lot better off in terms of public perceptions of its credibility than it is now.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The minister would be aware of the widespread concern within the Western Australian community at the WA government's decision not to participate in the National Environment Protection Council. Can the minister advise of the consequence of the WA government's refusal to be part of a genuine federal approach to environmental protection?

—Western Australia did indicate and reinforced its decision not to be involved in the National Environment Protection Council at a recent meeting of the Australia-New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council. At that meeting, the other members of ANZECC reiterated their commitment to the National Environment Protection Council initiative and indicated that enabling legislation would be in place in all jurisdictions by early 1995.

PARA.TAB: I can say to the Senate therefore that the NEPC will proceed without Western Australia. I note that the Western Australian government has been reported in the press as defending the indefensible in this case on the grounds that, firstly, different environment standards are needed in different parts of Australia; that the NEPC will be a new layer of bureaucracy; and that the NEPC involves loss of sovereignty by state governments. These claims, I can say to the honourable senator, are completely without foundation, as I think the Western Australian government knows.

I have written direct to the Western Australian environment minister, Mr Minson, pointing out that legislation passed by the parliament requires the council to take account of environmental differences. The NEPC will not be a new, large bureaucracy but in fact will involve a small secretariat drawing on the resources and expertise of the participating jurisdictions. Mirror legislation by state parliaments is required to establish the council, and implementation of measures will be the sole responsibility of the states.

The NEPC is an initiative of the states, not of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth, in fact, has only one vote on the council, which will determine national environment standards by a two-thirds majority.

The Western Australian government is denying the people of Western Australia environmental protection equivalent to that applying to other Australians, despite the clear wishes of Australians in this matter. Polling has consistently shown that the people of Western Australia want uniform national environmental standards. The Western Australian government is also denying industry the advantages of certainty in cross border simplicity by refusing to accept the same standards as all other states.

This is not a case of Western Australia resisting Commonwealth encroachment. In fact, Western Australia is losing the opportunity to contribute to the development of environmental measures that will apply not only to state jurisdictions but also to the Commonwealth's activities in the states.

Fred Chaney—who is well known to many honourable senators in this chamber—was recently reported as saying, `This seems to be a case of ideology overriding both commonsense and our involvement as Australians in a national issue.' When the Western Australian government comes to its senses on this matter, it will be very welcome to apply for belated membership to the National Environment Protection Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. In answer to a question from Senator Zakharov today, Senator Crowley told the Senate that the young homeless allowance was not available without verification of the child's needs. Is the minister aware that the verification acceptable to her department may be as little as a statement from a neighbour saying that he had overheard arguments in the house next door? If the minister does not believe the payment is a cause for concern in Far North Queensland, how does she explain expressions to the contrary from six high schools in and around Cairns? I wonder how she reconciles her views with those of Reverend Peter Laurence, of Trinity Anglican School, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: The allowance itself is of significant concern to many parents within my School community . . . The allowance seems to undermine much of what the traditional family unit stands for . . . I encourage you to pursue this matter.
When is the minister going to listen to the truth and reality, instead of her biased departmental advisers?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a non-inflammatory opener! I suggest that Senator O'Chee's people in Queensland would have a much easier weight of understanding of the truths of this matter if he were not saying the misrepresenting things that he is saying.
—Are the figures in Ravenshoe wrong?

—The figures in Ravenshoe, of going from nought to one, is one thing. Senator O'Chee fails to understand. On all the advice that I have been given, I believe that if a neighbour from over the fence rings the department and says, `Mary or Bill is behaving badly,' or something of that sort, that is never sufficient to constitute a claim. The claim must be verified and, in many cases, the parents are contacted.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty we have is in trying to find the proper balance between encouraging the support, rearing and caring for children within the family and, at the same time, recognising that some family environments are places that are very unkind to children. How do we protect children if they are victims of physical or sexual abuse within the home? How do we deal with the fact that sometimes children are not cared for by parents?

With the greatest sadness, we know that on occasions children are not well-off in their families. The government's policy is to try to encourage those children to be looked after by their families. It does not rush into paying children who walk in to the department and say, `I want the young homeless allowance.' If opposition senators know of any examples, they can by all means bring them to my attention. But they will find it is very hard to find some real examples; what will be found is preferred rumour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rot! Absolute rot.
—If it is rot, I would be very pleased to have the examples provided to me.
—There have been hundreds of documented precedents.
—There have not been hundreds of documented examples at all.
—Yes, there have been.
—No, there have not. I am reading out to honourable senators the process that must happen. A claim must be verified, because this is a matter of very serious importance.
—Tell us what adequate verification is.

—I have been through it, and I will go through it again. The claim must be verified. In the majority of cases the parents are contacted and, when it is inappropriate because of the nature of the child's problems, the claims must still be verified, often with teachers, child protection officers, family clergy or the like.

PARA.TAB: The government is trying to strike a reasonable balance in this very problematic area. It is not assisted by false and wild claims like Senator O'Chee's that we are breaking down families deliberately and expressly. If we were not paying the young homeless allowance, opposition senators no doubt would be demanding more assistance. As I said, I assure honourable senators that I will pass on to the minister any examples of real cases that people can bring to my attention and I will see that they are checked out. But the government's policy, which I understand is what is implemented, and which I know to be implemented, does not conform with what Senator O'Chee proposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Panizza this day, relating to the Telecommunications Ombudsman.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I asked a serious question.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were breaking your duck, were you?
—No, I was not breaking my duck. Senator Evans has not told us whether he won that game of golf. Having regard to the mood he was in, he probably did not.
—I improved a bit after the first hole.

—Did you? The point I am making is that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table, is entitled to defend his jobs for the boys, but when he attempts to defend it I believe he should give examples that are true and correct. In the case of Warwick Smith, he is far wide of the mark, because the ombudsman—
—You must be missing him at the moment. Do you wish he was here?
—I wish he were back here, and he will be back in due course, no doubt, if he wishes to come back.
—I think you might need him right now.

—All right; get off it. The point is that this is a unique situation, and Senator Evans should know that. All we got from the government with Senator Evans's garbled answer was an interjection from Senator Collins in defence saying, `Who owns Telecom anyhow?' That is all we could get from those opposite.

PARA.TAB: I will run through the exact situation. I said that the situation is unique. At present Warwick Smith is CEO of Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman Ltd, a company limited by guarantee and of which there is a board. The board provides funds to the company for the complaint services funded by Telecom, Optus and Vodafone. The structure is a council made up of consumer community representatives and industry representatives and a board of the funding organisation—as I have already told honourable senators, Telecom, Optus and Vodafone.

The council is the supreme policy making board, therefore not run by industry. The council contracted KPMG to run a nationwide search for a CEO. Warwick Smith was selected from 120 applicants for the position of ombudsman for a period of two years and has a contract with the board. He acts as CEO of the company, which reports by way of annual report and quarterly forums to the community. All staff are contracted to Mr Smith as CEO of the company. I repeat: he is not a government employee. With all that I have read out, I cannot see how, on 30 August, in his answer to Senator Hill's question, that the minister could name Mr Smith as a government appointment in defence of the jobs for the boys situation.

As I said earlier, I suppose the government is entitled to try to defend that situation but, by doing this, the minister must have been totally ignorant of the facts that he was talking about when he said that Warwick Smith was appointed by the government. I am pretty sure he was because, if I am not mistaken, he turned around and asked Robert Ray or Senator Cook what the situation was and they both gave him a blank stare. All I could get was an interjection from Senator Collins saying, `Who owns Telecom anyhow?'

All I can say to Senator Evans is that I wish him better luck next time in selecting who he thinks are government appointments from this side. Of course, Warwick Smith, the independent fellow that he is, is doing a very good job where he is now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—He is, and that is admitted by both sides of the parliament. I am sure he will continue to do a good job in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Chee this day, relating to the young homeless allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: In so doing, I think it is pertinent to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that this is the Year of the Family, and yet the Department of Family Services persists unabated in giving the young homeless allowance to many young children who are certainly not in desperate need, who are certainly not being sexually or psychologically abused by their parents. It is a fact that this payment is causing widespread concern in the community, certainly no less so in Far North Queensland.

PARA.TAB: In answer to a dorothy dixer, Senator Crowley tried to tell the Senate that I was scaring parents about the young homeless allowance. The young homeless allowance has been raised with me so many times this year that I have lost count. However, it is very clear that parents, headmasters and guidance officers at schools not just in Far North Queensland but right around this country are absolutely and thoroughly disgusted with the way in which this allowance is being handed out because, although Senator Crowley would have the Senate believe that there are all sorts of checks and balances on who is entitled to receive the allowance, the truth is definitely contrary to that point of view.

Senator Crowley told the Senate that a person could not get the young homeless allowance unless his or her need was verified.Yes, that is true. But what sort of verification do students need before they can qualify for the young homeless allowance? That is the question I asked the Senate. That is the question I asked Senator Crowley, and Senator Crowley did not have an answer for it. She cannot answer it because she does not monitor properly what her department is doing.

In one case that was raised with me by a principal and a guidance officer at a school in Cairns, a young child had approached the guidance officer on a Monday—apparently it is normal at guidance offices on Mondays for there to be a line of children outside the door wanting to get the young homeless allowance—and the guidance officer had said no, she was not going to provide verification; no, she was not going to support the application.

So what did the child do? The child left the office and went shopping for other people to support the application for the young homeless allowance. It sufficed in this particular case that the child in question got a letter from the next door neighbour who said yes, he had heard arguments in the house next door over the weekend. What house in this country with a teenage son or daughter does not have arguments on the weekend? It is in the nature of being a teenager to argue with your parents.

But the fact that a next door neighbour heard an argument next door does not mean that the child is being sexually abused and it does not mean that the child is being psychologically abused. It means that the child is having an argument with its parents. If that is sufficient to qualify for the young homeless allowance, then I am very concerned. It is not just me; thousands and thousands of parents around this country are very concerned as well. It is well known at schools in Australia today that all that children have to do is rock up with a story and within 24 hours they can be on the allowance.

One guidance officer from near Mackay told me that she knows of a case where a young girl went on the young homeless allowance at age 14 or 15, is now a drug addict and is now a prostitute—for the simple reason that the money at first sight seems a lot of money until they have to pay a few bills, until they have to pay for the unplanned expenses, and all of a sudden the money is not enough. That leads the children to petty crime, and in this poor girl's case it led her to drugs and prostitution. That is what the young homeless allowance is doing. In many cases—

TALK.START.PARA: —What a disgrace!

—Yes, it is a disgrace, Senator Forshaw. This payment is a disgrace, the government is a disgrace, and Senator Forshaw's contempt of the concern of Australian families is a disgrace as well. Senator Forshaw might like to cease interjecting and listen to the truth. The truth is that this allowance is breaking up thousands of Australian families and that many of the children are not homeless—they just do not want to be at home. I cannot put it any better than the Reverend Peter Laurence of the Trinity Anglican School, who in his letter to me said:

SPEECH.PARA: The allowance itself is of significant concern to many parents within my School community. I must say that I have grave reservations about it. There are considerable opportunities for abuse of payment to teenagers, with parents having no way of stopping it. The allowance seems to undermine much of what the traditional family unit stands for.

In answer to Senator Crowley, that was not sent to me after my press release went out. That was one of the things that prompted me to send my press release out. And I stand by it, and I stand by my position on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a re-run, Senator O'Chee. I am very pleased to take the opportunity in the few minutes provided to me here to suggest that Senator O'Chee is getting carried away. To suggest that the young homeless allowance is responsible for leading women to prostitution or to becoming drug addicts is an absolute scandal. What is Senator O'Chee's thesis? His thesis is that he wants to kick heads, really, I think. He actually goes a long way to stirring up and aggravating this confusion in the community about the young homeless allowance and whether or not teenagers can rock up—thousands of them, to quote Senator O'Chee in another scandalous piece of misinformation—to guidance officers. As I said to Senator O'Chee during my answer in question time, only 300 people under the age of 15 are on this young homeless allowance, and 1,400 people aged 15. That comes to 1,700 people, hardly Senator O'Chee's thousands of people rushing around this country.

PARA.TAB: We can check out the examples that Senator O'Chee gave, if he wants to be serious about it. If a child lines up on Monday to say to a guidance officer, `Will you say that I have had a rough time at the weekend over home?', the guidance officer says no and so the child looks for some other kind of support for the story—if that is all the evidence that is forthcoming, I would like to know a little more detail about it because any proper examination would find just what he said is the case: that arguments over the weekend are not unusual.

We do not need teenagers to have good arguments. And there can be arguments from Monday through to Friday too, but there may not be a neighbour at home to hear it so easily. Of course arguments happen but they would never be seen as sufficient justification for a child to walk out.

If Senator O'Chee wanted to say that getting the balance right is a very difficult matter I would take him very seriously. It is a very difficult matter and that is why the Department of Social Security has been concerned with this matter. I might say to Senator O'Chee that the social security department is not my department. I represent it here, and am very pleased and proud to do that, but he needs to be sure it is a social security department matter that we are talking about.

That department has listened over the years to evidence raised in estimates hearings. I well remember a very constructive meeting when the then Senator Walters, the then Senator Peter Baume, the then Senator Richardson and I discussed across the table the fact that families could not be reassured by the Department of Social Security that their children were okay because there was the matter of protecting the children's privacy.

The department has examined the protocols and made absolutely sure that it has made them as tight and serious as it can. I think that, importantly, it has got the balance right in making sure that the children who are in need of support and protection are provided with it and that, at the same time, children who are having a spat with the family are not encouraged to take the first dollar and go. It is much more constructive—that is why I stand by my earlier comments—to find the facts and talk about them instead of whipping up a frenzy.

If the case Senator O'Chee raises has any substance and if he would like to bring it to the department, I will certainly see that the protocols are examined and, if anything further can be said about such a case, it will be followed up. I have no doubt about that at all. But to suggest that the young homeless allowance is leading to prostitution and drug addiction is a pretty wild and, I think, mischievous claim. It is not helpful to parents who might have a concern about what is best for their children and how they can be assisted in caring for them, particularly disputatious teenagers.

It is also very concerning for government to know that there are children whose families do not provide them with protection, support, love or constructive arguments and which are a hazard to their children's wellbeing. The state department and the Commonwealth, through the Department of Social Security and this payment, need to assist those children and offer other support mechanisms to provide care for the children.

It would be much better for Senator O'Chee to write back to the headmaster and tell him the facts of this matter, or pass the letter to me and I will seek an answer on it, rather than for him to go around saying, `Even he says we are inflaming passions.' That is not what he said. He said, `It is a matter of concern.' Indeed, if it is a matter of concern, let us sort it out instead of inflaming things.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was listening to the debate between Senator O'Chee and Senator Crowley. Just for the record, over the last two years there have been five cases—three of which I dealt with personally—where parents, one of which was from Launceston, have contacted my office, saying that their children had been enticed away by other young homeless people because of the extra money they were getting. Those cases were settled and it was proved to be right that young people who were street smart were enticing other youth out of their homes on trumped up charges. I can get the details of these cases for Senator Crowley. They happened last year. I know that Senator Newman has knowledge of dozens of other cases.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Chris Evans this day, relating to the National Environment Protection Council.

SPEECH.PARA: In Senator Faulkner's answer, which related to my home state of Western Australia, he criticised the Western Australian government for not joining with other states in relation to the National Environment Protection Council. I wish to point out to the Senate that when that body was first thought of there was a lot of enthusiasm and optimism because it was thought that environmental laws should be uniform. However, as the states began to examine the matter more closely, it soon became readily apparent that, with Australia being the vast country that it is, the states have differing needs in relation to the environment and that the states' different geography and requirements had to be taken into consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —But should you opt right out?

—Senator Faulkner recognised these different requirements. He said that the legislation would allow for different regions and states to have their needs taken into account. I believe the Western Australian point of view is that, if we do not need the NEPC, why join it? The Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, ANZECC, was the previous mechanism for achieving consistency throughout Australia—and that answers Senator Kernot's question. A mechanism is already in place for consistency throughout Australia, and that is ANZECC.

PARA.TAB: I would venture to say that the Western Australian view is that that body is able to do a good enough job without our having to have uniform laws across the country. This in turn says that we have to take each state's situation into account. Why have that legislation when it is not needed? It really goes to the efficiency of government and why we should make a law when it is not really needed.

This is not a case of the state being obstinate and it is not about saying that this body is, in a ideological sense, something which is wrong or bad. It is more the practical argument that this body is not taking us any further and that ANZECC is a much more practical solution to the issue at hand. Therefore, I think Senator Faulkner's criticism of the Western Australian government is quite unjustified. We can argue this issue on ideological grounds as well, but Senator Faulkner was saying that the Western Australian government was acting entirely on ideological grounds and that it was throwing out something of use in favour of an ideological stance. That is simply not the case.

Recently there has been a compensation query in relation to the noise levels at Sydney airport. I wonder whether the minister has looked at whether this will have universal application across Australia in relation to airports. The situation in Sydney could well be different from that of, say, an airport at Broome, Western Australia. Does the minister, by his NEPC, envisage setting uniform requirements for compensation payouts? I bet that will be a pertinent question—one which might liven up the minister somewhat when we start talking about uniform compensation. Having regard to the government money which could be at stake, that is something about which the government would no doubt be most concerned.

That is the issue at hand. It is not an ideological stance; it is really a practical stance. I believe that the minister was distorting the position when he put in the way he did the position of the Western Australian government in this instance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —To remind honourable senators, we are dealing with the proposed amendment to section 191N(6) which refers to the tabling of the national indigenous land strategy in the parliament, allows for it to be disallowed and provides that whilst that period waiting for the disallowance is in train nothing can be done in relation to that strategy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell aptly summed up the position of the coalition on this point. Subsections (8) and (9) are proposed because one really does not get very far when one simply tables the strategy in the parliament without having some consequential action on it. If accepted, the people who are affected by this strategy would have some form of redress via their elected representatives, senators or members of parliament, to have it disallowed if necessary.

It would have to be a very serious matter indeed to have a majority disallowing the strategy; we fully appreciate that. One would not envisage a national strategy being disallowed, but the proposed amendment is there in case the strategy goes against the majority of thinking in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. If the feeling is that this strategy has missed the boat, there is an avenue of action that can be pursued.

I understand that some other senators find proposed subsection (7)—that is, the tabling of the strategy—to be not such a bad idea. It does place it under some sort of purview. I do not think the government takes much issue with this proposed subsection either. A great deal of legislation has strategies and regulations which can be disallowable instruments, but the first thing is for it to come under the purview of parliament. We are proposing to take it that step further by making it a disallowable instrument in accordance with the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

It is not as though we are trying to hold up the implementation of the strategy; this is designed to give a second chance for comment by those who are intended to be the beneficiaries of this national strategy. And if we have that, it naturally follows that we have subsection (9)—that nothing should be acted upon something which could be disallowed. I do not think that in the normal course of events the delay would be that great. It is conceded that there is a possibility that there could be some delay if there were a break in time, such as over the Christmas break or the winter break. In the normal course of events that would not happen but I take that argument on board. That is the reason the coalition has inserted proposed subsection (9).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have already put on the record that we are not intending to support proposed subsections (8) and (9) of opposition amendment No. 20. However, I did defend the opposition from some criticism that I felt it was getting, undeservedly, for even contemplating a disallowance capacity in regard to the tabling of the strategy. By that I did not mean to raise Senator Campbell's hopes. Had he given me a moment to speak on the last occasion we were considering the bill, I would have laid his hopes to rest. The Greens are not intending to support proposed subsections (8) and (9).

PARA.TAB: Once again I state quite clearly that because we feel that the ILC is very close to being a government body, even though it has the capacity to appoint five Aboriginal people of the seven people to be on that board, it is still too much of a government body for our liking. Because it is like a government body, it is appropriate for it to table its strategy and it is appropriate in some situations that that be considered a disallowable submission to the parliament.

The Greens do not support this amendment because with every amendment we have been trying to move the ILC away from being a government body so as to be more in line with Aboriginal people in the community. So we see supporting this amendment as actually reinforcing what we believe to be undesirable—that it should be a government board that is quite appropriately able to have its strategy disallowed or made a disallowable document.

Secondly, even were we to give in on that point, we oppose the amendment because we do not believe that the parliament in its current imperfect form reflects the views of Aboriginal people in the community. Whether the parliament will ever do so is a debatable point. So our feeling is that the amendment would not allow more Aboriginal people to have access through the parliamentary system unless we radically altered our party political basis for decision making. That is the other reason we remain unconvinced.

As we have said, we are happy to support the tabling of the national strategy document as a public information, on-the-record kind of measure that is very useful. We note that the government has already said that there are several parts of the bill that allow that to be widely disseminated on request, and that is commendable. Therefore, we do not feel it necessary to support the second and third parts of this proposed amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I have just one more crack at it, Mr Temporary Chairman. I did have the opportunity to discuss this with Senator Chamarette privately. She certainly did build up my hopes. It was a terrible thing to do; I have been agonising about it all weekend!
—Did you manage to get the seat next to her on the plane back to Perth?

—No, I did not. Senator Chamarette and I have shared planes all around Australia as members of the native title committee. However, I do understand her concern—the Greens (WA) do want to try to make the ILC as independent as possible. I have thought of an example, which may not be a good example but it is the best I can do at the moment. I have in mind something like Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank—the Commonwealth Bank pre-privatisation, anyway—which have a requirement that their reports be tabled in the parliament. Since I have been a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration the committee has called members of the board of the Commonwealth Bank before it and cross-examined them about their report. So even organisations as remote now as they are from the Commonwealth in terms of management and decision making can still be subject to public scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: The point that Senator Ellison makes is a good one: if the ILC comes down with a national strategy which does not reflect the hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people, there is still no mechanism for Aboriginal people to have any effective control over or leverage against the ILC board. So I appeal to Senator Chamarette not to regard parliamentary scrutiny as some form of government intrusion into the ILC. Although the ILC is being made more dependent upon the Australian parliament, this is a way of actually making it less dependent upon the executive. I am appealing on the grounds that the parliament is not the executive, as Senator Chamarette knows better than most. The powers of the Commonwealth parliament, which are quite unique, can be used to make the ILC more independent from government. That is the basis of our appeal not just to support subsection (7) but also to support subsection (8). This would ensure that not only would the document be required to be tabled but also this parliament would be given the power to disallow it.

The effect of disallowing it is basically to say, `Look, you've done the consultation that the parliament has imposed upon you. You've gone out and spoken to people.' I am reminded that Minister Tickner in particular and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have told this parliament that the government has gone through the widest consultation in the history of Australia in relation to this bill. Senator Chamarette has been told that; I have been told that. Those of us who have taken an interest in this bill know that that is not the case. The government has spoken to whom it wants to speak and heard what it wants to hear.

We are saying that, even with the consultative provisions that we have put into this bill with the support of the committee—the fact that the board must now consult with Aboriginal groups and not just the ATSIC regional commission—it is still quite possible that the board would come up with a national strategy which did not reflect the hopes, aspirations and views of the Aboriginal and Torres Straight Island people that it seeks to serve. Through this mechanism—that is, requiring the strategy to be tabled and then giving the parliament the power to disallow—the real people that are being empowered are the Aboriginal and Torres Straight Island people and more scrutiny is being put on the ILC board.

As Senator Harradine pointed out last Thursday, the fact of the matter is that the board is a government creation—the minister does have that power. We are saying that here is a nice effective check to enable Aboriginal and Torres Straight Islander people to say to the board, `You'd better listen to our views. Don't just consult with us but listen to us because if you don't and your national strategy doesn't reflect our views then we can go to people like Senator Chamarette, Senator Ellison, Senator Kernot and Senator Gareth Evans even and say we don't like this strategy. If you're not listening to our views then we'll ask people like Senator Chamarette, Senator Campbell or Senator Collins to disallow it.' That makes the board accountable to the people, actually reduces the links between the government and puts more power in the hands of the people. That is the effect of the amendment. So I would make one final plea for Senator Chamarette to reconsider her position on the second section of coalition amendment No. 20.
