TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: D1.Clause 3, page 25, proposed subsections 192W(2) to (5), lines 1 to 17, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:
" `(2) The Land Fund is a fund under the control and management of the Indigenous Land Corporation.
`(3) The Indigenous Land Corporation is to keep a Land Fund Account, separate and distinct from any other account, recording payments into and out of the Fund.

`(4) So far as practicable, money in the Land Fund that is not required for the functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation must be invested, but may not be invested other than in the manner for the time being authorised by an Act or a State or Territory Act for the investment of trust funds.'.".
D3.Clause 3, page 26 to 32, proposed sections 193A to 193H, line 23 (page 26) to line 40 (page 32), omit the sections.
D4.Clause 3, page 33, proposed subsection 193I(1), line 3, omit "The Minister", substitute "The Indigenous Land Corporation".
D5.Clause 3, page 33, after proposed subsection 193I(2), insert the following subsection:
" `(2A)The Indigenous Land Corporation must forward the report to the Minister as soon as possible after the completion of the preparation of the report.".
D6.Clause 3, page 33, proposed subsection 193I(3),line 21, omit "completion of the preparation of the report", substitute "receipt of the report".

The series D amendments that the Greens are putting relate to the Indigenous Land Corporation's capacity to own and control the land fund. We will not be putting our amendment D2, which relates to the splitting of the money between the ILC and ATSIC. We are doing that because we have not been successful in omitting section 191U, where the requirement in the legislation is that none of the ILC fund can be used under the Northern Territory land rights act. It is still within the bill, and on that basis we can see why the Northern Territory, at least, would be very anxious regarding the failure to maintain the split between the $21 million going to ATSIC and the $21 million going through the ILC.

PARA.TAB: These amendments are to proposed section 192W and consequently omit a series: 193A, 193B, 193C, et cetera. Under the bill, the land fund is a trust account within the Commonwealth public account. As such, the fund is owned and controlled by the Commonwealth government. Investment of the money in the land fund is to be made by the Minister for Finance or his delegate within the Department of Finance or ATSIC.

The Greens (WA) believe that the Indigenous Land Corporation should own and control the land fund in its own right. We see that the proposed structure of the land fund falls a long way short of the level of self-determination bestowed on Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory by the Fraser government in 1976 in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The New South Wales parliament passed legislation in the mid-1980s which allowed the New South Wales Land Council to manage a fund which will eventually be worth more than $500 million. That model of the New South Wales fund allowed 7 1/2 per cent of all land tax collected in the state to be available for investment and immediate funding over a 10-year period. It is a much better example of self-determination.

The less overt reason for the land fund being kept within the public account is so that it does not affect the budget deficit. If it is within the public account, then the government never has to come up with the billion dollars—not in one year and not even after 10 years. I think that is a myth being perpetrated in the media upon the public. They have been told repeatedly that Aboriginal people stand to gain a $1.4 billion fund. I think it is time to lay that to rest, not just in the community and in the media but also in the legislation. If the $1.4 billion never leaves the public account and stays in consolidated revenue so that it never upsets in the slightest bit—except by $45 million a year—the budget deficit, then it is not a fund being given to Aboriginal people or to the ILC: it is a government fund. All that happens for the ILC is that it actually has an expropriation from that government money of $45 million a year.

I do not think the government can win both ways. It cannot say, `We're giving $1.4 billion to Aboriginal people under this fund,' and on the other hand say, `But we're not affecting our budget deficit much at all, only by $45 million a year.' If the government is to have a $1.4 million fund, it should give it to the right people and not continue with this pretence. As we know, all that the ILC is coming up with each year is $45 million—and even $21 million of that is old money—so the budget deficit will only be affected by $24 million a year out of a total deficit that is expected to be $12 billion. So we believe very strongly that the focus of these amendments is to try to give that control and self-determination principle to the ILC so that it has got the capacity to look at the way in which the money is invested, look at the possible earnings and have a much greater say in it than is currently allowed for under the legislation.

I will say one more thing before I open the debate up to my colleagues to comment on this factor. The government might argue—in fact, I have heard it argue—that it gives Aboriginal people certainty. I think that is true—it will. I have even heard the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, say that it will be a great shame if this bill does not pass because Aboriginal people will not then be locked into this wonderful $1.4 billion fund. I want to make it quite clear on the public record that there is a very good reason that Aboriginal people should not be locked in to an increase of $24 million a year, which is meant to meet the justice requirements of the Prime Minister's purpose for this fund, which is to redress the dispossession of all Aboriginal people or at least the 95 per cent who do not stand to gain by native title.

I think there is a political reason for this locking in and that is that it takes the land acquisition needs of the Aboriginal community off the agenda for 10 years. So, politically, it may be high risk if it is not locked in but, on the other hand, for Aboriginal people it is an extremely high risk if it is locked in because it allows very little chance of increase. So what we get is the lowest common denominator. Why should the Aboriginal people forever be locked into the lowest common denominator of $45 million a year by this legislation?

I think, if the amendments that we will be considering later in the `A' series are taken seriously by the government and the quantum is actually increased, the Aboriginal community could stand to gain by having something favourable locked in. But to lock in something that is $21 million a year is a disgrace. That is why these amendments seek to give the control of the money and the land fund to the ILC.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be very forcefully opposing these amendments. I fundamentally dispute the points that Senator Chamarette so carelessly laid before us a few moments ago about the downside of Aboriginal people being locked into this fund and about this being done purely for political purposes, as she said. There is an obvious benefit to the Aboriginal people who are the sole beneficiaries of this fund being locked into a guaranteed return on the fund; that is, in respect of all the vicissitudes of international economics that could occur in future years. We have just been through one major international recession which we are only just coming out of. That could happen at some future time.
—Just coming out of?

—I am talking about the international recession which is still hanging on in various places around the world. The recovery has only just begun in a few major countries. In fact, there are a few major democracies that are still in some disarray.
—Yes, Australia!

—Let us not pick that example. Let us pick any other example that Senator Panizza does not interject on. The benefits are palpable—that is, Aboriginal people, through thick and through thin, will be guaranteed a return from this fund of which they will be the sole beneficiaries. Quite simply, no sound reason has been advanced for the fund to be removed from the public account, which would be the effect of these amendments. The government opposes them.

—With regard to the comments Senator Chamarette made about the quantum and structure of the fund's moneys, I think those comments are accurate. But I think where we part company with Senator Chamarette is that she believes that $21 million to $24 million a year is worse than nothing. The Democrats believe that, while the money may be inadequate, it is not worse than nothing. More than that, in actually putting in place 10 years of appropriations, we are doing something that we have not done in this place before.

PARA.TAB: I think we ought to consider political reality here. The fact is that this government and this opposition are both reluctant and negligent in their lack of desire to honestly discuss revenue raising for the things this country really needs to pay for in its future, and that is in respect of a whole lot of services, not just what we owe Aboriginal Australians. Given that we know that that is a political reality, I think it is very unlikely that future governments will place a high priority on a land fund. If we were to defeat this bill, I think it very unlikely that future governments would re-visit this debate. While I agree that this money is a very, very small amount to redress what is needed by way of compensation for dispossession—I do not know whether we have got enough anywhere in this country to do that—given that we are getting a 10-year appropriation, a small appropriation, I cannot agree that it is worse than nothing.

Senator Chamarette says there is a high risk if we lock this in. I think history tells us otherwise. History tells us that if we do not take action now, we will get nothing in the future. So inadequate it might be, but I am going to vote in favour of a 10-year appropriation because I certainly do not think it is worse than nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put the coalition's position on the record. In reality, much of what Senator Chamarette said is right. What has really been achieved in the world of political reality, which is the world of political perception, is that the government has created in the minds of people and Aboriginal people a $1.4 billion fund. I congratulate the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, and the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, for the deception they have created in the minds of the people of Australia. When we go out into the communities—we sometimes get let loose on the weekends, or when the bells ring on Thursdays and we get let out for a few hours—and talk to real people, the perception is that this land fund is a $1.4 billion fund. So I congratulate Mr Tickner and Mr Keating for being politicians in the worst sense of the word, for being Goebbellian politicians, because they have achieved something incredible—they have achieved the perception in the Australian community that there is a $1.4 billion land fund.

PARA.TAB: There are two reasons why that perception is unfair. Firstly, for those people in the community who believe that Aboriginals get too much already, that the money is wasted, and who say, `Why should we give Aboriginals something that white people can't get,' of course, it is a good can to kick. For redneck people who want to kick the Aboriginal can, it gives them a nasty, almost racist can to kick. Secondly, for the Aboriginal people and those who care about trying to do something to redress both their dispossession and their disadvantage, it is a hoax because, as has been pointed out by Senator Chamarette and Senator Kernot in two different ways, what this bill effectively does is to appropriate $24 million a year. It does not appropriate $45 million; it appropriates $24 million. As I have pointed out on a couple of occasions, that is roughly—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is money to ATSIC.

—I understand that, but that money is old money; it is already going there. So the new appropriation is $24 million. As I have said to Senator Chamarette privately, and publicly now, over the years up to the year 2000 it is actually less than Senator Faulkner announced as the gold medal plan or the Olympic athletes program. It is less than the money we are giving to a handful of elite athletes and sports.
—Are you advocating more money for the fund?
—No, I did not say that.
—I just thought I would clarify that.

—I am putting it into perspective so that people can understand. I am sure that just about all Australians would agree we should help to fund our Olympic athletes and help our sports get ready for the Olympics in 2000. Certainly, when I do the coalition's sports policy, I am not stupid enough to say we should be tinkering with that.
—Where do Aboriginal people fit in your priorities in terms of the amount?

—In terms of my commitment to Aboriginal people and Aboriginal issues, I am very vulnerable at the moment because the next time I ask Senator Faulkner a question on sport, I am sure he is going to say, `Senator Campbell has been the shadow minister for sport for six months and this is the first question I have got.' So in terms of my priorities—
—And he would be right.

—He would be quite right. People in this chamber know that I spend an enormous amount of my time on Aboriginal issues. I have spent an enormous amount of my time in the last couple of years travelling around Australia, meeting Aboriginal people.
—Because you're on the monitoring committee. Did you do it voluntarily?

—I have done it voluntarily for years before that; Senator Kernot does not know me that well. In fact, I got the committee set up, as she quite properly knows, because this government forgot about it.
—And I voted for you.

—Senator Kernot put me on the committee. I thank her for her vote. So let us not talk about who cares most about Aboriginal issues. We should not get into that debate. We all have our cares. Senator Panizza knows the amount of travel I do in outback regions and how much time I spend talking to Aboriginal people. So let us get back to the debate we were having before Senator Collins interjected.
—I am being the best behaved person.

—Senator Collins is doing well today. In terms of the proportionality of it, and the amount that is being appropriated under this bill, it is not a $1.4 billion fund, as Senator Chamarette pointed out; it is in fact $24 million of new dollars each financial year.

PARA.TAB: The reality, from the coalition's point of view, is that we have looked very carefully and long and hard at this concept of keeping it inside the public account or putting it outside the public account. We remain unconvinced that taking it outside the public account will help Aboriginal people. I think that is the point that Senator Collins has made. At the moment this bill assures for the next 10 years an appropriation in the terms that I have mentioned. We therefore remain unconvinced that the scheme that is outlined in the D series of the Green amendments will achieve any more.

The coalition has publicly recorded that the concept of the land fund is supported and the appropriation level is supported, and that is to give a commitment into the future. So no scaremongering can occur during the election campaign by saying that the coalition will abandon the land fund. That is on the record. The coalition will be committed to it. We have said, as has been widely reported, that we have some preconditions, but I must say for the record that many of our amendments have received government and even Democrat support—I should not say that; I should say that they have received unanimous support. I place that on the record. When many of the amendments were put in the House of Representatives, the opposition was told that they would not be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have changed them and changed them.

—They fundamentally recognise some of the principles that we put in the House of Representatives. Certainly we finetuned them and we brought in new ones. But the reality is that the Senate is working as a much better house. It is actually passing many of our amendments with unanimous support, and other amendments with the support of the Greens (WA) and Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: We have said that we will be supporting the legislation if those amendments are carried. As we know, most of those amendments have been carried. That is the position of the coalition. As I said, we remain unconvinced as to whether or not the series D amendments would be of assistance to Aboriginal people, and we believe the risk is perhaps higher than the upside, on the balance. I know the Democrats have also looked very closely at this question and have come to the same conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to some of the comments that have been made and to note that we are discussing two issues. I think I may have strayed a little in getting on to the amount because basically the aim of amendment D1 is that `the land fund is a fund under the control and management of the Indigenous Land Corporation'; is to be kept `separate and distinct from any other account, recording payments into and out of the fund'; and `so far as practicable, money in the land fund that is not required for the functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation must be invested, but may not be invested other than in the manner for the time being authorised by an act or a state or territory act for the investment of trust funds.'

PARA.TAB: While I do think it is an interaction effect with the paltry amount of money, the major point of these amendments is that the money is essentially not in the control of the ILC. So it is a structural amendment that asks why they should not have the right to determine the investment and the capacity of that fund. The models that we feel are superior to that are those put in place in 1976 in the Northern Territory, where there is an advisory committee for the trust account that gains money as a result of the Northern Territory land rights act. The trust account is operated with ministerial approval of payments. The minister is advised by the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account Advisory Committee, of which the minister appoints the chairperson and the land councils elect the 14 members. That committee has the receipt of income, which is royalty equivalents, interest earned on its own investments and other minor receipts, and it is able to allocate it.

The total of royalty revenue equivalents passed on to the trust account in 1993-94 was a little over $32 million. In addition, $1.6 million was earned in the investment income. We have a model, and it is a model of self-determination. We are moving a long way back from that in this particular fund. We also have the model that I referred to earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ABTA is in the public account; it always has been.
—The point I am making is that the board actually has the capacity to control and use that funding and to be involved in the investments.
—So will this board.

—I will seek the minister's clarification, rather than interjections, on the public record because I believe that the structure of that account is far superior in terms of self-determination principles.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the New South Wales Land Council's fund, it has the responsibility to receive the 7 1/2 per cent of land tax each year and to invest 50 per cent for the benefit of a self-sustaining fund in 10 years time, and it has the capacity to distribute and allocate the other 50 per cent of revenue it receives each year. The structure is an important one and I think that needs to be supported as the main reason for this particular amendment.

With regard to the other comments that were made, Senator Collins said that the benefit is indisputable for those Aboriginal people who are the sole beneficiaries of this fund. What I would want to say there is that it may well be in the interests of those who end up being the beneficiaries. The problem is that there is a vast percentage of Aboriginal people who will never be beneficiaries of this fund, because of the amount. Therefore, it is not necessarily a good structure that we are putting in place because the government is actually keeping the bulk of the funding within the public account and not distributing it. Nor is it allowing Aboriginal people and the ILC to have a say in the investment of that so-called $1.4 billion. Each year we are not allowing them to invest the $200 million or $121 million, depending which year, to maximise the expropriation that they might be able to receive. That is the link with the amount. Because they have so little, if they had more say in the money that is being kept in the public account, that is, the $200 million that is there this year and the $121 million that is in that public account for the next nine years, they would be able to maximise their return.

In fact, in the committee hearings we heard some very interesting testimony from J.P Morgan that the fund is diminishing because it is being kept in the public account and that it would be possible, if the investment was diversified, to increase the amount by which Aboriginal people could benefit. That is another major reason for allowing the money to be outside the public account and for the ILC to be able to control the way in which it generates income, which will then be available to Aboriginal people.

Senator Kernot said that if we defeat this bill future governments will not do it. She also said that history tells us that if we do not take action now we get nothing. There is one flaw in that. History also tells us that governments tend to get away with as little as possible. Once they have put in place and locked in as little as possible, it is extraordinarily difficult to get them or any other government to increase it. We always get a lowest common denominator. We get: `What can we get away with giving—the minimum amount with the least disruption.' Then forever after, because the political capital has gone to make that change, further improvements are so unlikely as to be wishful thinking.

I know that this government has a responsibility, because the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said so. He has said that it is part of his major financial contribution, as a result of the Mabo High Court decision, towards amelioration of the dispossession of Aboriginal people of this country. If this is the major proportion, heaven help Aboriginal people.

If we put this bill in place and we then allow the government to rest on its laurels, because with this structure and with this amount of money it has quite a good deal, then no doubt it will never do anything again. It has not made any commitment to increase its action on this particular bill and it will be able to gloat over its human rights stand internationally as though it has actually met its human rights obligations to the indigenous people of Australia. So I think there is a very important reason why we should not say, `This is the best thing and it should be put in place.'

Finally, I will talk about the gold medal plan that Senator Campbell raised. I think it is not entirely a coincidence. It might not have been a deliberate intention of the government, but I think it portrays a subconscious attitude that $21 million actually is the unit of nothing appreciable at all to affect the budget deficit. We can give $21 million a year to our Olympic athletes as part of the gold medal plan—believe me, I am not asking that that be reduced—but I think it is the smallest unit that can escape out of the budget allocations without causing disruption. It should be noted that that is the same amount that is being allowed to escape to Aboriginal people to redress the injustice of 200 years.

I do not think that these things are entirely unrelated; they are not simply equivalent units. It is enormously useful to the government to provide funding of $21 million as the gold medal plan for our athletes in preparation for the Olympic games, and it is enormously useful to this government to provide Aboriginal people with a land fund, into which they are locked, of $21 million a year. When there is protest at the Olympic games over Australia's failure to address the dispossession of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country, that will be rebuffed by the government being able to say, `Oh, no, we have you locked in. We have given you all the redress that you are going to get.'

Maybe I am being overly cynical, but I am afraid there is an accuracy in what I am saying. This small amount of money over the next 10 years, which the ILC has no ability to increase, is supposed to silence the protests and pleas of the Aboriginal peoples who will not be sole beneficiaries of the fund in any way, shape or form, nor will they have any say in how it is being allocated or in how the investment earns an increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about this section of the legislation. I am inclined to the view that has been adopted by Senator Chamarette for a couple of reasons. The first is that, unless that view is carried forward in the legislation, the true budgetary position will not be readily appreciated by the public while the fund is contained as part of the public account.

PARA.TAB: The second reason is based on an economic and consistent point of view. Another of the government's welcomed initiatives was the superannuation guarantee levy. The government decided that the levy was required because the ageing of the population meant that revenue would not be able to fund superannuation after people retired. I have had arguments with the government about the fact that the taxpayer and the consumer are now really paying what the government should have been paying out of consolidated revenue. Nevertheless, the government said that there should be this superannuation guarantee levy. Where is that put?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a charge.

—Yes, it is a charge. The government does not allow employers to keep that money in their `consolidated revenue', in their company account. The government insists that the money is placed in superannuation management funds which are then managed by the superannuation industry. This is an example of something which is very important to many people for sustenance—in this case, in the time of their retirement—but the government does not allow employers to keep the money in their running funds or their particular account.

PARA.TAB: Here it is different. Why? I do not know. Whatever the amount the government has decided on, why can the government not ensure that it is managed by the board? Investment seems to me to be an appropriate way of proceeding. It recognises, as Senator Chamarette said, that the Senate, thus far at least, has indicated to the government the importance of ensuring the empowerment of the Aboriginal people through the board. I would like the minister to respond to the question of why the government takes one attitude in respect of superannuation for the population at large and another attitude in regard to this particular matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did intend to canvass all of these issues; I just did not want to cut off debate. There is one significant difference, of course, between superannuation funds and this fund, which I would have thought was obvious—that superannuation funds are not public money and this is. I would call that a very substantial difference.

PARA.TAB: There are a few other things that I want to clarify in trying to deal with all of these matters at once. I do not understand, frankly, Senator Chamarette's reference to the ABTA—a body with which I am very familiar in the Northern Territory—as a model on which this fund should be based. In fact, I am astounded by that being used as an example.

I am very familiar with the advisory council of the ABTA. In fact, I know personally all the people who are on it. That is precisely what it is, it is an advisory committee. The decision maker in respect of the ABTA is the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The minister, in fact, makes the decisions about where that money goes. There are some delegations to the advisory committee by the minister, but they are at his discretion. The minister can determine from time to time what levels of reserves have to be kept in that account. There was a period not so long ago where very few disbursements were made from the ABTA. The minister controls it completely and is the decision maker for it. So I cannot understand that reference at all.

I note that on page 32 of this bill there is a reference in clause 193G(1) to a meeting convened by the minister at least once each financial year—I think there are some proposed amendments from the Democrats to this section—a meeting of various people that the minister puts together, as he does the ABTA advisory committee, to advise on the investment policy of the fund. It would be very similar in its nature to the way in which the ABTA currently operates with its advisory committee, with the minister having the final decision making role which, of course, is dramatically not the case in respect of what is being proposed here.

The fundamental reason for the government placing this fund in the public account is to ensure maximum security for the fund. That is unblushingly the case. As part of the public account, this fund will be governed by certain provisions of the Audit Act that protect Commonwealth moneys. The range of investments permitted under section 62B of the Audit Act is limited to more secure forms of investment.

There is a risk of capital losses from the fund if it is invested in less secure instruments—and I might add that this was a matter of some prolonged debate in cabinet consideration of this issue. If that were allowed, it could in the long term jeopardise the viability of the fund. The bottom line at this time is that the fund is being placed in the public account essentially to ensure the maximum security for the fund.

I must say that I take considerable exception to the dismissive way in which the amount of money under this fund is dealt with. This amount of money is provided simply for the specific purpose of providing additional benefit to the Aboriginal people of Australia. What annoys me about the references that have been made by Senator Chamarette and others is that they have referred to the fund as if it were the only measure of financial assistance to Aboriginal people. Entirely fallacious and flawed comparisons have been made with gold medal assistance to Olympic athletes and so on.

The facts are that government outlays for the benefit of Aboriginal people, which this government provides and strongly supports, are in the order of $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion a year. ATSIC alone receives, from memory, in the order of $900 million a year at this time—and it will escalate in future budgets—which is disbursed for the benefit of Aboriginal people. DEET, for example, currently gets around $300 million a year in terms of specific training programs for the benefit of Aboriginal people. The state and Commonwealth housing arrangements, with which I am also familiar, currently provide in the order of $100 million a year for housing—I think it is $95 million, to be precise—for the benefit of Aboriginal people. The total sum currently being expended, in rough terms, is $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion in existing outlays of public money a year—which this government provides and strongly supports—for the benefit of Aboriginal people. So those comparisons are sadly flawed.

This amount of money, which I think has been carefully considered by the government in terms of its quantum, is in addition to that very significant amount of government support, for the benefit of Aboriginal Australians, that is already provided. The bottom line, in respect of the public account—I might add that the ABTA is operating within the public account—is fundamentally to provide the maximum security for the fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for clarifying that. I was not totally familiar with the process. I did like the increased level of Aboriginal community input to the ABTA and the fact that it has regional representation on its board, something the ILC cannot have because it has a board of only seven people. There cannot be representation to the same degree as the ABTA advisory committee has with 14 elected members. We can see they have greater input. I was in error in assuming that their say in regard to the investment of the money was somehow greater or different from that proposed for the ILC.

PARA.TAB: I still would say that it is a matter of concern. I would like the government, through the minister, to say how the figure of $200 million that remains in the public account—and the $45 million to be expropriated—was determined. How did the government choose that amount to remain in the public account and how did it choose the $1.4 billion that remains in the public account? If the government has been publicising that it is a $1.4 billion fund for Aboriginal people, how has it justified the fact that the $1.4 billion is all in the public account? I would like some answers to that. Also, what is the government's position on the effect on the deficit if the $200 million—or a greater amount—was able to be outside the public account or was somehow available to the ILC in terms of control of the investment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer to those questions is that the $200 million was a start up for the fund. That global amount was set in a way the government sets all these dispersals of public money. Unfortunately, we do not have the facility that the Greens have; which is not having to worry about putting budgets together—basically just printing the stuff for everybody who asks for it. We do not have available to us the magic pudding approach to budgets. I assure Senator Chamarette that the global amount was considered after lengthy consideration by the government as to the total budgetary commitments that it has. So there is nothing magic about the $200 million. That amount was simply determined as the amount to get the thing going.

DEBATE.TITLE: TABLING OF INDEXED LISTS OF DEPARTMENTAL FILES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That the order agreed to by the Senate on 28 June 1994 and amended on 10 October 1994 requiring each Minister to table certain lists of specified files held by Government departments be revoked.

(2)That the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) table in the Senate by, and not later than, the close of the first day of the 1995 Spring Sittings, indexed lists of file titles, comprising the titles of all files relating to the policy advising functions of the department, including any relating to the development of legislation and other matters of public administration created between 1 January 1995 and 30 June 1995 inclusive in the central offices of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Social Security, but not including the titles of routine files, titles containing sensitive matter or the titles of files of a specified class.
(3)The Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee evaluate the success of the trial.
(4)For the purposes of this resolution:

TAB.TAB: (a)`1995 Spring Sittings' means the period of sittings of the Senate first commencing after 31 July 1995;
(b)`indexed list' means:
(i)a hard copy of a list of file titles grouped by classifications used within the relevant departments, and
(ii)an electronic copy of a list of file titles grouped by classifications used within the relevant departments;
(c)`routine files' means:
(i)files transferred to Australian Archives,
(ii)case-related files (such as personal representations, files on particular departmental clients or taxpayers), and
(iii)files related to the internal administration of the department (for example, staff and personnel files);
(d)`sensitive matter' means matter that discloses:
(i)commercially confidential information,
(ii)personal information, as that term is defined in the Privacy Act 1988,
(iii)information disclosure of which would be prejudicial to law enforcement or to the defence or security of Australia,

(iv)information about the internal deliberations of Government, including Cabinet, where disclosure would be damaging to the public interest, for example, by premature disclosure of policy initiatives, or
(v)information damaging to the Commonwealth's relations with other governments, including State and Territory governments; and

(e)`specified class' means files identified or marked with a national security classification or other confidentiality identification or marking such as Cabinet/staff/commercial-in-confidence, or which contain internal working documents relating to the formation of policy initiatives, disclosure of which would not be in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion now before us, of which notice was given last week, deals with quite a complicated matter with a long history. It is one of rather fundamental importance for effective administration in this country. I would like to say to Senator Harradine and members of the opposition who are interested in this that I want to do three things. First, I want to give an account of the history of this matter. In doing so, I want to make it clear that there has been no deliberate backtracking or bad faith on the part of this government, notwithstanding some suggestions to that effect that apparently had been made. Secondly, I want to explain why it is that the government supports the motion, of which notice was given last week and which is now in front of us. Thirdly, I want to address the question of what happens if this motion I have now moved is not agreed to by the Senate. I want to do all those three things.

PARA.TAB: As to the history of this matter, I think the course of events needs to be appreciated if there is not to be some perpetuation of misunderstandings here. Things began back on 16 December 1993 when Senator Harradine gave notice in the Senate that he would move a motion stating:

That there be laid on the table by the Leader of the Government . . . of the budget sittings 1994 . . . an indexed list of every file . . . held by each Commonwealth Department, grouped under classifications such as policy, legislation, advising, general matters, administration or such other classifications as are most commonly used across departments;

SPEECH.PARA: There was a further qualification, however, that that list was not to contain `any information which would disclose commercially confidential, identifiably personal or national security information.' Although qualified in character, nonetheless, the motion proposed by Senator Harradine was of enormously broad ambit.

PARA.TAB: On 3 March 1994 in the context of a rather lively debate we were then having on another matter to do with government ministerial accountability, as part of the government's response to that debate—I quote from page 1454 of the Senate Hansard of 3 March—I announced:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, we will support, subject to further discussion on detailed drafting, motion No. 544, notice of which was given by Senator Harradine on 16 December 1993. That motion would require publication by way of tabling in parliament of departmental file titles relating to policy matters, legislation and the like.

So I gave a clear-cut undertaking in this parliament that we would support, subject to further discussion on detailed drafting, Senator Harradine's motion. That detailed discussion then took place. It was a protracted process, and it involved a lot of discussion between me and Senator Harradine and our respective offices. That culminated, in terms of the documentary trail, in a letter that I wrote to Senator Harradine on 27 June 1994 proposing a motion in terms that were attached to the letter, which was certainly not a comfortable position for the government to adopt. I was well aware that, within the government, there was a great deal of reservation and concern about the practicability of that commitment. But I took the firm view with Senator Harradine that I was obliged by the undertaking that I had given and wanted to act in good faith and to do so particularly before the Senate got up at the end of that session.

PARA.TAB: On the following day, 28 June, just before we rose, the motion that was moved in the terms which I had conveyed to Senator Harradine in that letter was in fact agreed to by the Senate. The motion provided for a two-tranche commitment to be made by the government. The terms of that motion, I suppose, are most clearly referred to in the appendix to the Senate committee report, which report I will refer to in more detail in a moment.

The particular motion that was passed provided in the first place that not later than 10 October 1994 an indexed list of the titles of all relevant files created between January and June 1994 be tabled. The second tranche provision related to files created between June and December 1994. They were to be tabled not later than the end of the first week of the first sittings in 1995. Those were the terms of the motion that was passed by the Senate. They were the relevant dates that were set in that resolution.

That resolution, however, was referred on a motion by Senator Vanstone on behalf of the opposition to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for consideration and report. There was manifest concern on the part of at least some spokesmen or senior members of the opposition that maybe this whole files business may be unworkable. At that stage maybe members of the opposition were thinking that they might be in government at some stage in the future and were worried about the implication of this kind of extremely intrusive resolution. In any event, since there was time between June and the first reporting date of October—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was that manifest? Where was the opposition's concern manifest?
—Unlike some others, I do not like to retail the content of private conversations—
—But it was not publicly manifest, then?

—I do not think much was said on the floor of the Senate about it, but there was a concern. I think the nature of that concern was more clearly manifested in the response of opposition members when they got to the committee itself, but I will come to that in just a moment.

PARA.TAB: For whatever reason, the motion adopted was in fact referred to the committee for report. That took place. That was the next stage of the business. That turned out to be a rather more protracted process than had been anticipated. Part of the reason for that, I frankly acknowledge, was that it took a long time for the government to prepare and agree upon the terms of a submission to that committee.The terms of the government's submission were ones that reflected the very real concern in the executive government ranks as to the workability of the resolution, the nature of the commitments that were being made and indeed the utility of the information that would appear as a result of all this extraordinarily time-consuming effort.

Nonetheless, I want to draw honourable senators' attention to the terms of that government submission because they are relevant to this question of good faith and whether or not the government has behaved in a consistent fashion. If senators have the terms of the committee report in front of them, they will see that that report contains the full text of the government's submission. If they turn to the concluding part of that submission, paragraphs 59 to 63, they will see the following points made. I would appreciate leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of those paragraphs, because then I could just summarise them rather than reading them.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: CONCLUSION

59.The Government's agreement not to oppose Senator Harradine's motion (in its amended form) was based on the understanding that there was majority support for it, related as it had been to the accountability package debated in the Senate on 3 March 1994.

60.In the event that, notwithstanding the difficulties identified in the Submission, the majority support continues, the Government will make its best endeavours to comply with the terms of the order, noting that it is essentially a trial arrangement to be reviewed in 1996 when a more considered assessment of the value of the information provided and of the costs and any problems associated with providing it can be made.

6.In the light of the concerns expressed by departments, which are shared by the Government and reflected in this Submission, the Committee may wish to consider, having regard to the views of the parties in the Senate and its independent members, whether to recommend:
that the order come into effect according to its terms;
some modification of the order; or

PARA.TAB: that the order be revoked.

SPEECH.PARA: 62.Possible modifications that would make the order easier for departments to comply with include:
reducing the duration of the trial period from two years to one year;
removing the current element of retrospectivity so that files required to be listed could be identified at the time of creation;
this would be achieved by omitting paragraphs (1)(a) and (1)(b) of the order; and
providing for class exclusions, in particular for all files having any national security classification or other confidentiality marking such as Cabinet/Commercial/Staff/etc-in-Confidence.
63.Were the Committee minded to recommend that the order be revoked, it may wish to consider making recommendations:
reinforcing the fullest use of the various existing arrangements to enable Members and Senators to be kept informed of the activities and thinking of departments; and

calling for the early enhancement of the capabilities of the parliamentary databases and for the development of arrangements for them routinely to include departmental documents tabled in the Parliament.

Indeed, the Committee may see a role for itself in undertaking a more far reaching inquiry into the scope that developments in information and communications technology may have for improving accountability and the provision of information from Ministers and their departments to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will read the first two paragraphs because they are the key ones. Paragraph 59 states:

PARA.TAB: The Government's agreement not to oppose Senator Harradine's motion (in its amended form) was based on the understanding that there was majority support for it, related as it had been to the accountability package debated in the Senate on 3 March.

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph 60, which immediately follows, states:

PARA.TAB: In the event that, notwithstanding the difficulties identified in this Submission, the majority support continues, the Government will make its best endeavours to comply with the terms of the order, noting that it is essentially a trial arrangement to be reviewed in 1996 when a more considered assessment of the value of the information provided and of the costs and any problems associated with providing it can be made.

SPEECH.PARA: In the remaining paragraphs of that conclusion we went on to point to the nature of the concerns which had been expressed by departments, suggesting that, in the light of those concerns, the committee might wish to consider, having regard to these various views, a different approach than simply adopting the order in its original terms. I refer to paragraph 60 because that was a clear statement from the government—in fact, it was endorsed by the cabinet—that, in the event that majority support for Senator Harradine's motion continued, the government would make its best endeavours to comply with the terms of the order. That position still holds, and I will come back to that point a little later on.

PARA.TAB: That is what was said by us in making our submission to the committee. I will not go into the substantive content of the submission; I will summarise that briefly in a moment. I just want to get the history of this clear. On 20 September the committee reported. This was a committee which had three government and three opposition members. The report was unanimous. There was no minority report; it was a unanimous report. The conclusions of the committee—again, without going to the reasoning—were threefold. The committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.the order of 28 June 1994 be revoked;
2.the Government give notice of an appropriate substitute motion which would implement a trial production of indexed lists of departmental files for two departments for six months; and
3.the trial not involve any retrospectivity and exclude appropriate classes of confidential files as suggested by the Committee.

So in its report the committee is saying, `Put aside the original motion'—even though it was agreed to in the Senate back in June—`Don't try and track back retrospectively and produce lists of files for the past', which would be unworkable, costly and time consuming, `but start now and produce some for the future. Don't do it across the whole range of departments. Just take two selected departments and do this on a trial basis. Then we will come back and look at it again on the basis of that trial experience.'

PARA.TAB: That is what the committee reported. Senator Kemp was on the committee. Senator Watson—who is much respected in this place for his approach to administrative matters as well as his indefatigable determination to keep the government honest—was also on the committee. And Senator Campbell, who is in the chamber at the moment, was on the committee as well. They all put their names to this report; it was a unanimous recommendation. And, I believe, it was a good faith recommendation with everyone understanding that it was stepping back from something that the government—and the Senate—had agreed to do. Nonetheless, it was a stepping back in light of the accumulated weight of the evidence that was before the committee as to how all this might work.

On 10 October, which was the reporting date in the original motion—procedurally, something had to happen in the Senate by that date—there was agreement in the chamber to actually amend the original motion to put a date of 10 November rather than 10 October. I think it should be frankly and honestly acknowledged around the chamber that this was simply a device to defer the whole question for a month while the government drafted the trial motion that had been recommended by the committee. The government could not do that immediately because there had to be consultations within the government as to which two departments would have the honour of bearing this particular responsibility. It was a tricky issue to resolve and it was going to take time. We told people that in the consultative process that occurred.

I am not suggesting that Senator Harradine was especially comfortable with all of this because he saw us moving backwards from the original terms of the recommendation, but others in the chamber—particularly the opposition—were comfortable with that, and on those terms. I believe it was understood around the chamber that the purpose of substituting that date was simply to defer the debate for a month. I think it is also reasonable to say that there was an expectation—certainly on the government's side—that the majority that had made itself clear in the committee would hold up on the floor of the Senate and that there would accordingly be support in this place for a trial process of the kind recommended by the committee.

By the end of October the government had resolved which department would do this trial: my own department, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, was to be one, and the Department of Social Security was to be the other. The Department of Social Security is a large operating department with a lot of practical program delivery dimensions as well as some policy dimensions. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is a large policy oriented department. We thought that this was a fairly reasonable spread which would give us an indication of how workable this system would be.

At the end of October people were given advice of the government's intentions in this respect. Last week, on 8 November, I moved the motion that is now before us which provides for the revocation of the original June order and provides for a trial exercise on a prospective basis of the two departments concerned. We were ready to debate that motion the following day, 9 November, before the formal time for the production of documents under the original order fell due. Last week, the opposition asked for more time to consider its position on this. Although that produced some technical difficulties about us being in breach of the Senate order, we were happy enough in all the complicated circumstances of this matter to grant that extension of time. Thus it is that the matter comes on for debate today rather than last week.

That is the history of the matter, as objectively and as frankly as I can describe it, with all the instances of what occurred along the way. As to the arguments for the motion in the terms in which I have moved it and as it is before us on the notice paper, let me just say fairly succinctly these things. The committee was asked by the Senate to examine a number of specific issues: whether the order in its original form would in fact produce material which was in a user-friendly form for senators and others; the practicality of implementing the order; the cost of carrying it out; the implications of the order for Commonwealth departments; and whether any more efficient and effective method might be devised to achieve the objectives of the order.

Manifestly, the terms of reference were sympathetic to the idea behind the order, but nonetheless they sought a pretty wide ranging review of its practicalities, both from a Commonwealth department's point of view and from a user's point of view. The government, as I say, provided a considered submission to the committee which, in the substantive part, pointed out that there were serious practical and other difficulties. We identified difficulties relating to the number of files involved, the usefulness of file titles, the ability of departments to implement the order in the time scale outlined if retrospectivity were required, and there were also serious concerns about the availability of certain classified material.

It appears that the committee—it says so in its report—found the government's submission persuasive and shared its concerns over these practical and other difficulties. The committee particularly felt that the retrospectivity involved in the earlier order would not easily be workable and that the order should be modified so that it had an entirely prospective application.

The committee also shared the government's concerns about the possible damage that could arise from premature disclosure of material relating to policy initiatives, and that a government was entitled to have its departments develop policy advice in confidence. The committee also agreed with the government's submission that provision of the information of the kind sought would probably not be of much practical benefit to the parliament, and that the cost and resource implications of the exercise under those circumstances could not be reasonably justified. I think that is a fair summary of the basic thrust of that committee report which, as I say, is signed by Senator Kemp, Senator Watson and Senator Campbell as well as the three government senators. There were no minorities and no majorities about this; it is the unanimous considered recommendation.

The committee did go further, however, than the government's submission and recommend that a limited trial should occur. The committee was not prepared just to say, `No, don't go on with this'. It said, `No, you should have a go at making this work,' proposing that it should, however, be prospective rather than retrospective, and that it should exclude certain classes of files. The committee considered that it should apply to only two departments and operate for a period of six months.

As I said, the government's motion now before the Senate is intended exactly to give effect to those unanimous recommendations of the committee, embracing both the opposition and the government. If we look at the terms of the resolution on the notice paper we will see that paragraph (1) revokes the previous order; paragraph (2) establishes the new limited trial and provides that on the first day of the 1995 Spring sittings, which is currently scheduled to be 22 August, the Leader of the Government is to table lists of files created during the first six months of next year in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Social Security; paragraph (3) provides for the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee to evaluate the success of the trial as envisaged by the former standing committee; and paragraph (4) provides for a series of definitions, most of which go to describing the kinds of files which are to be provided.

I am extremely conscious that this motion does not go as far as Senator Harradine would have liked. It is certainly not as extensive in its scope as the order that was agreed to at the end of June. But it does represent an honest attempt to come to grips with some of the immense practical difficulties involved in making this work in a way that is not just manageable for governments—that is only one side of the equation—but also in a way that is actually helpful to users, that is, people embarking on an exercise of finding out what government is up to and addressing their minds to policy issues and so on.

I think the motion is eminently reasonable in its terms. I think it is fair enough for me to say that two big and serious departments are involved, not just small and marginal departments. We get ample opportunity to look at the range of issues that are thrown up by this sort of administrative exercise. There will be ample opportunity to evaluate and make a decision as to whether this should continue on a more comprehensive basis.

I hope the Senate can respond seriously to the kinds of points that I make. I could go on at much greater length about the terms of the government's worries about this—the terms of the Senate committee report—but I think I have perhaps said almost enough to make that clear. However, I should say something about what the government's position will be in the event that I have not succeeded in persuading the Senate and it does not want to revoke the original order and does not want to support this proposal for a trial period that has been put by the committee. If that is the case, I am forced back on the undertaking given in the submission put to the committee. I do not propose to resile from that. I will repeat paragraph 60, which is in these terms:
In the event that, notwithstanding the difficulties identified in the Submission, the majority support continues—

SPEECH.PARA: that is to say, the majority support for the original order—
the Government will make its best endeavours to comply with the terms of the order, noting that it is essentially a trial arrangement to be reviewed in 1996—

And so on. So we will make our best endeavours to comply with it. There is an obvious difficulty in complying with the order in the terms in which it is expressed at the moment, because the date for doing so has already passed—even the original date of 10 October for the first tranche and now the second date, 10 November.

PARA.TAB: I have to say frankly that we cannot comply even this week, or next week or the week after, with this because the work simply has not been done. The reason the work has not been done is that for the last couple of months at least, since the committee has reported and, indeed, when it was known from talking to people what their likely views were, a reasonable judgment was made that something at least would come out of the committee report which would be different from that which was in the original motion. Under those circumstances, work has been put on hold for this. It has not been put on hold in my own department—we have been gearing up to do it, and Social Security similarly—but in the other departments it has.

As a result, there will be a very real difficulty in meeting quickly any requirement for retrospective tabling. I would accordingly have to ask that those dates be further amended. I hope we could be given till the first sitting week of next year for the first tranche being sought and, for the second tranche, maybe six weeks or so after that—the latter part of March—as a realistic time frame for this.

In terms of the nature of the problems the departments are experiencing and why it is a practical necessity to have this amount of time, I refer honourable senators to paragraph 29 of the government's submission to the committee, which goes specifically to the question of the practicality of implementing the order in its original terms. There are lots of other parts of the submission that go to cost and to the utility of the information thus derived, but paragraph 29 goes to the question of practicality. It says:

A number of departments would be able to comply with the order if its application were to be delayed until appropriate changes were made to records management systems software. Even so, further consideration would be needed of the nature of the classes of files excluded from the list (eg Cabinet, security classified and commercially sensitive files) and manual checking of titles would still be necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: It gives some detail in support of that:

PARA.TAB: eight departments commented that the suggested categories system is inappropriate. Most departments have their own indexing systems which allows them to locate files by subject at a far more detailed level or on a different basis (eg work units) than the classifications proposed. In addition, many files would appear in at least two out of three categories (were the suggested classifications to be adopted) since policy and legislative matters, and commonly advisings, will often be contained on one subject-matter file;

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the point is made:

PARA.TAB: eight departments noted that the inclusion of files already created, and the excision of sensitive information from file titles would need to be done manually, and in most cases by officers of appropriate experience and/or seniority to make judgments on individual files, and information contained in file titles. Most of these departments noted that this would be costly and time consuming, and would divert resources away from normal operations. It may be that if class file exemptions could be made most of this work could be undertaken electronically, with only a manual final check;

SPEECH.PARA: I interpolate there, however, that we are not in a position of having such class exemptions, only the very broad ones that I have already mentioned. The submission goes on:

PARA.TAB: five departments noted that compliance with the order could only be achieved with system changes of varying degrees of magnitude, or consultant assistance;

two departments noted that there could be security concerns in complying with the order although it is possible that these could be alleviated were files with a national security classification to be excluded;
one department suggested that there should be additional file class exemptions to the order to protect commercially sensitive information affecting the department itself.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a measure of the particular practical problems that are going to be experienced right now. The retrieval systems are simply not in place just to press electronic buttons and get the results wanted. The classification systems do not coincide with the ones in the terms of the resolution. It is just not the way departmental files are organised. To go back retrospectively for files that were not created with this disclosure exercise in mind is an inordinately time-consuming business. It is for these reasons that we wanted to do it—if we were going to do it at all—prospectively rather than retrospectively, so that at least people could develop systems that would enable the information to be readily retrieved. That is the nature of the problem. That problem is a stark one.

PARA.TAB: To try to go down the path of meeting Senator Harradine's terms of the original order in a matter of days or even a few short weeks would simply be impossible. The time frame I have mentioned is one that takes into account the original time frame in the original motion. The motion was passed at the end of June. The report date was 10 October. I am not asking for a full four months in this instance, but I think we need at least nearly 2 1/2 months to be able to do the job properly—taking into account the reasonable expectations people had that they would not be confronted with this kind of obligation.

I am sorry to have been so long-winded about this but I think it is necessary, given the heat that this seems to be engendering in some quarters and the misunderstanding it is engendering in others, for me to make very clear that the government really has tried to act in good faith throughout on this, but it has been an intractable set of practical problems that we have been wrestling with. I had not appreciated the magnitude of those practical problems when I made the original undertaking to Senator Harradine back in March. I sensed that there were going to be a few and that is why I was careful to say `subject to detailed consideration of drafting difficulties'. I made clear to Senator Harradine that there were going to be some problems about that. There was a reservation or a qualification made in good faith, and I hope that Senator Harradine does not feel that he was dealt with in bad faith over the months that followed when we tried to wrestle with the terms of this.

It was not our proposal or idea to refer it to a committee; that came from the other side of parliament. We, in making a submission to that committee, made it clear that, while we felt there were some agonising practical difficulties involved in implementing it, nonetheless we would make a best-endeavours effort to do so in the event that the committee was not persuaded by those practical difficulties. The committee came out with the unanimous report which embraced those practical concerns and suggested a reasonable course of action which we are now prepared to embrace.

I know Senator Harradine will be a bit disappointed about it and think it is a step backwards—he has said so quite robustly to me on several occasions—but I hope that he will accept at least that I and the government have been trying to act in good faith and that it is just an inherently difficult issue. I hope that some good sense will prevail and the opposition will follow the judgment of its own committee members, who have had more time to look at this issue than perhaps anyone else in the chamber apart from those of us immediately involved. I recommend the terms of the motion to the Senate accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to speak now?
—Yes, it's your agenda.

—No, it is not my agenda at all. I would have thought, and I felt at the time, that this was a matter that would have been the agenda of a person like the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, who has had a marvellous track record of verbal support of open government.

PARA.TAB: I was most heartened when, after discussions in March, an undertaking was given by Senator Evans in the terms that he has outlined today. In the month that followed there was discussion. It is no good saying that there was not discussion with other departments—there were discussions between Senator Evans's office and other departments. What emerged, finally, in June was not my motion but a motion, the terms of which were agreed to specifically by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I would have thought that was it. I was very pleased because I felt that that was an advance towards open government.

Senator Evans would not have been surprised when I found that the government's submission to the Senate committee looking at the Freedom of Information Act said that the act is concerned with the principle of open government; that it does not prescribe government in the open. That is an extraordinary Sir Humphrey statement. I believe that the Senate will find the nicety of such a metaphysical distinction of no practical benefit at all. Maybe the government itself might wish to explain what that means.

So here we have the opportunity to advance the principle of open government which the Leader of the Government has supported for some considerable years. Indeed, the Australian Law Reform Commission, in its issues paper No. 12 of September 1994 on freedom of information, refers to the motion that was adopted by this Senate in June. The ALRC states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Electoral Administration Review Commission in Queensland addressed the need for information about its files by providing a publicly accessible database of its files. Other approaches include publishing file lists in the Government Gazette or several times a year in separate digests that would be available at public libraries or through AGPS in hard copy or on disc.
That was after the statement by the ALRC that:

PARA.TAB: Sections 8 and 9 ensure that the public is provided with a certain amount of information about the documents agencies hold. This information may not always be sufficiently detailed to assist FOI applicants to identify particular documents. The difficulty is probably greatest for documents that do not contain the applicant's personal information. Concern has been expressed in Parliament that lack of information about agency files causes applicants to incur unnecessary search and retrieval expenses and thereby makes them unable to utilise the Act fully. In response to a motion by Senator Harradine in June 1994, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is inquiring into the practicality, cost and implications of requiring government departments to table in Parliament twice a year an index of files created in the previous six months.

SPEECH.PARA: And then mention is made of the EARC. This is not only designed to be an enhancement, an adjunct, to assist persons who undertake FOI exercises; more importantly, it is an important adjunct, an important tool, that can be used by the parliament for the purpose of its audit and control of executive government function. Thus, I was very pleased when this motion was adopted in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I discussed the matter with Senator Vanstone before she moved the amendment to refer the matter to the Senate committee. From memory, a decision was made that the order should come into effect on 1 September, or the date of the report of the committee, whichever was the earlier. I was given to understand by Senator Vanstone that the addendum was designed to have the committee examine not whether relevant departmental files were to be produced but how they could be more effectively produced in a user-friendly manner. The government make a submission to the committee. The committee asked for only one submission, and that was from the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —To be fair, the terms of reference of the committee were much wider than that. The terms of reference, at the beginning, were much wider than you are suggesting.

—I am not saying that that was the extent of the terms of reference. The terms of reference were wider. But the point that was made to me by Senator Vanstone—and I do not think it was made in here because it was agreed by me that that ought to take place—was not whether but how the indexed list of file titles would be tabled. The government, however, did not take that view. The government itself indicated to the committee, as Senator Evans pointed out to the chamber, that it did not wish to have the responsibility of tabling the indexed list of file titles.

PARA.TAB: Some of the statements that were made by the government were quite extraordinary, and I might just mention a few of them. The minister talked about the submission to the committee. I would like to talk about the statements that were made in the submission that the motion was retrospective. There is no genuine retrospectivity in the sense that it is used in the parliament in the order—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not suggesting that. It is only retrospective in the sense that there are pre-existing files rather than newly created ones and, therefore, you have classification and retrieval problems.
—How do you mean classification problems?

—Because they have been classified without regard to the language of the obligation now upon the departments. Therefore, in the absence of electronic gadgetry to do it quickly, you have real problems other than by full manual exercise, going back and pulling them apart.
—No, they are not pulled apart. We are talking about file titles. We are not talking about what is contained in the files. That is something that will need to be looked at.
—That's your next agenda.

—What is wrong with that? I am not the government, but I do not want to be kept in the dark, nor do my constituents. There is no genuine retrospectivity. The file titles are simply examined to see whether they fit within the terms of the resolution which, I remind Senator Evans, was identical to the terms that he agreed to.

PARA.TAB: A number of reports suggest that there would be problems with the number and the usefulness of the files. That is contained in the government's submission. In regard to the number of files, many of the files created would relate to the personal affairs of taxpayers and the recipients of government payments and would, therefore, be outside the scope of the order. If there is a case where a department activates a large number of files each half year dealing with policy advice, legislation et cetera, electronic database searches could be used for identification purposes.

The comment in the government's submission as to the usefulness of file titles makes me wonder at the logic behind the submission. Presumably, file titles are useful to the department; therefore, it would seem they would be useful to the parliament. If file titles are useless to the department—and, therefore, useless to the parliament—that is a reflection on the administration, which I cannot help. I thought that was a very strange comment to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be useful to the person working on them.

—Yes, and if he or she happens to be run over by a bus, presumably it is useful to the next person who takes the job. But to be so useful, it would need to be properly titled. The registries, which are now somewhat regionalised, should also know what is useful and what is not. The suggestion in the government's submission that policy initiatives would be compromised if meaningful titles were produced is, in reality, an admission that the listing of the file titles would assist parliament in its scrutiny of the actions of the executive. It is also an admission that, if the parliament and the public were involved in policy formulation at an early stage, it may affect the policy. What a dreadful thing that would be!

PARA.TAB: Is that not what open government should be about? Is that not what we in the parliament should be about? It is hard to reconcile the government's suggestion that the file list would be of little practical benefit to the parliament. On the one hand, the government says that it will be of little practical benefit to the parliament; on the other hand, the government says that the parliament and the public may have too much say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take a sensitive foreign policy initiative which you might be contemplating or something like that: you can't flag these things to the universe.

—I am coming to that. Senator Evans knows that we dealt with those matters. They were contained in the resolution in June. I will not go any further on this aspect. I will not talk about the costs, because they were extraordinarily elastic, and Senator Evans knows that. They were unbelievably elastic. Paragraph 37 of the government's submission says:

PARA.TAB: Although it would be a most regrettable development were it to occur, the possibility should at least be recognised that the requirement to table file lists could, in some limited circumstances, lead to two possible highly undesirable practices, namely, use of less informative, even deliberately obscure, file titles and delaying the creation of files (and thereby jeopardising the proper custody of papers) until the subject had ceased to be of particular sensitivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Was the government serious about that? The government is saying that there could be a deliberate obstruction by the provision of false file titles. It says that that would be regrettable; indeed, it would be. It would be even more regrettable from the point of view of the public servants who may do that in an effort to thwart the order of the Senate, adopted by the elected representatives of the public, if the Senate decided to use its powers to ensure that that order was complied with.

PARA.TAB: I believe that there is a need for a cooperative approach. That is why I entered into those discussions with the minister. I am concerned about a number of matters. I am concerned about the institutional memory of various government departments. I have dealt with at least one case in respect of a government department where that institutional memory was lost. As a result, a decision was made by bureaucrats without regard to the matters that should have been on file.

Having dealt very briefly with the government's submission, I will not pursue it too much further. As a matter of fact, I have something here which does a bit of a `Sir Humphrey' job on it. It is probably too much like light reading, but I will give an example. Paragraph 1 of the government's submission says:

Successive governments have taken seriously the provision of information about the administration of departments and agencies and the operation of government programs as part of the Executive's obligations of accountability to the Parliament. The nature and form of the documentation through which this information is provided has evolved and the Government would argue that the Parliament, and through it the public, has available to it today more information of practical use in analysing and assessing the performance of government than at any previous time.

SPEECH.PARA: In plain English translation, the interpolation by Sir Humphrey Appleby would be this: `We are giving you more than we want to give you, and we don't want to give you anymore.'
