It must, however, be conceded that this is a masterly opening gambit by Sir Humphrey. It is an extraordinary statement. Paragraph 2 of the submission says:

PARA.TAB: Even so, the Government fully realises and accepts that the inevitable changes over time in the way the executive arm of government operates and the likely continuing evolution of the scrutiny role of the Parliament will necessarily involve a constant reassessment by both Parliament and government of Parliament's requirements in this regard and as a result, the nature of the information provided and the form of documentation will no doubt continue to develop.

SPEECH.PARA: Did all honourable senators understand that?

TALK.START.PARA: —A perfectly sound proposition.
—I think in plain English it means—
—You hear it said all the time; we understand it.

—Yes. It is really saying, `Unfortunately, you have us over a barrel and I suppose we might have to give you something.' That is what it is saying. I am not prepared to go through that sort of frivolous exercise. I want to go to the guts of the matter and the difference between what the government is now proposing and what the terms of the Senate's order are. The key difference is the number of file titles and the nature of the file titles to be tabled. The scope of the files for which file titles are to be tabled is dramatically reduced by the government's proposal.
—Because of the two departments and the qualifications.

—It is only the two departments, that is true. But I am talking mainly about what is in the order relating to relevant files and what is in the motion. Files bearing a national security classification or other confidentiality in identification are excluded, and files which contain working documents relating to the formation of policy initiatives can all be excluded. That means virtually every policy file—
—Disclosure of which would not be in the public interest, is the qualification.
—Not that again!

—Yes. Who decides? It is a good question, Senator Evans: who decides that? As will be noted by the Senate, it means that virtually every policy file can be excluded from the listing if the government is to decide what is or what is not in the public interest. By contrast, the order of the Senate contains words to the effect `agreed upon between Senator Evans and me'. It only allows exclusion of a part of the name of a file title if that part would necessarily disclose commercially confidential, identifiably personal or national security matters. Again, those were the words that were agreed. It was clear to both Senator Evans and me that they were needed to avoid the situation that we will get into now where the department can simply exclude the title of any file, the disclosure of which it deems would be damaging to the public interest.

PARA.TAB: The key words in the order of the Senate include the word `necessarily'. One excludes a file title if that part would necessarily disclose commercially confidential, identifiably personal or national security matters. Senator Evans hit the nail on the head when he suggested the words `in the public interest'. I am sure the Senate will see that it is important that we stick with the order, which is quite definite on that matter. The way `file title' is defined, it means the name or title of the file, excluding any part of that name or title which would necessarily disclose commercially confidential, identifiably personal or national security matters. It is important that the parliament take a stand on this matter, ensure that this order stand and that the government be invited now to do what it said it would do and cooperate with the order, as it said it would.

I give this undertaking to the Leader of the Government in the Senate: I would be prepared to agree with what he has suggested might necessarily need to be done if the order is retained intact; that is, I would seek leave, after this motion is determined, to amend the order so as to enable the start-up date to be as suggested by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As I understand it, the first tranche to be the first sitting day in—

TALK.START.PARA: —The end of the first sitting week.
—In January. And the second tranche to be when?
—The third sitting week in March.

—I am sure the Senate would understand that that would be desirable to ensure the full cooperation of the government and the government departments in this exercise, which is essentially to enhance the principle of open government and availability of information to the public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter originated with Senator Harradine's notice of motion on 16 December 1993, which I understand was recorded as notice of motion No. 544. Senator Harradine gave notice that he would move as follows:

PARA.TAB: That there be laid on the table of the Senate by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) not later than immediately after question time on the third day of the budget sittings 1994:

(a)subject to paragraph (b), an indexed list of every file title held by each Commonwealth Department, grouped under classifications such as policy, legislation, advising, general matters, administration or such other classifications as are most commonly used across departments; and
(b)the list of titles referred to in paragraph (a) is not to contain any information which would disclose commercially confidential, identifiably personal or national security information.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms we are obviously supportive of more open government. We were certainly prepared to enter into a dialogue as to whether such a proposal, if passed, would significantly contribute towards providing members of the public with information upon which they could then be more confident as to the proper conduct of their government. We believe lifting the veils of secrecy on government is, in general terms, in the public interest, subject to proper safeguards which obviously include enabling the government to go about its business effectively—issues of national security, personnel and the like.

PARA.TAB: But Senator Harradine's notice of motion was overtaken by other events. The principal event was the sports rorts affair, which, as you will remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, was an appalling incident of government abuse when government used principally taxpayers' money through sports and recreation grants to advance its political interests. Basically the then minister was caught out when she was unable to demonstrate publicly how one grant was given over another—how one applicant was successful over another that was not. That really demonstrated the whole political bias of the sports rorts program of this government.

Of course, the sports rorts affair was not set up by that minister; it was set up by former Senator Richardson. We on this side of the chamber were particularly interested in getting to the background of that particular program really, I guess, to evidence a case through public knowledge that would ensure better behaviour by governments in the future. What we have seen, particularly of Senator Richardson, is that when the heat is put on, he resigns from his ministry, as he did over the Marshall Islands affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the motion before us?

—It has a lot to do with it. It is how it came about; it is why we are here today. I know Senator Evans is very sensitive to this because an inquiry into his part in the Marshall Islands affairs was avoided by the resignation of former Senator Richardson and then the determination of the Australian Democrats that there was no good purpose to be served—
—Thanks to Miles Kupa.

—He blamed Miles Kupa and blamed his officials. Basically, the Australian Democrats and other minorities then decided there was no purpose to be served in a Senate inquiry into the circumstances of the Marshall Islands affair. Senator Evans breathed a great sigh of relief and business went on as usual. This was very similar because we proposed that there be such an inquiry also into the sports rorts affair so that the whole of that sordid business would be put on the public record and governments would ever learn a lesson. But when it came to the vote in this place, certain arrangements—
—The same minority—

—The Democrats voted against it again, I think. The Australian Democrats go out there and claim to keep the bastards honest, but each time it comes to the crunch, each time it becomes a little bit too sensitive for a minister, they vote with the government and say, `Public inquiry and public information are not in the public interest and therefore we will vote down the suggestion of an inquiry.' In this instance, instead of such a public inquiry, which would have been of great benefit to the public in terms of information as to how this government goes about its business and, in particular, how it abuses taxpayers' funds to advance its short-term political goals, the minorities in this chamber did separate deals with the government and then voted against our proposed inquiry.

PARA.TAB: As I recall it, the Australian Democrats reached certain agreements with the government which resulted in them voting against our inquiry. Senator Harradine, as he is well entitled, made an agreement with the government as well, which led him to vote against the inquiry. Part of that agreement concerned undertakings given by Senator Evans in relation to Senator Harradine's notice of motion No. 544 which I read out a moment ago and which he had given late the previous year. What did Senator Evans promise in relation to that? He promised in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally we will support, subject to further discussion on detailed drafting . . .

Only discussion on the detail of the drafting, not discussion on the principle at all, not discussion on the number of departments, not discussion on the information to be given, just the detail of the drafting, the mechanical functions of putting it in proper order. He said he would support motion No. 544, which is that which I read. I will quote it in full because it ought to be properly on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on the record.
—Senator Evans has owned up, has he? He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally we will support, subject to further discussion on detailed drafting, motion No. 544, notice of which was given by Senator Harradine on 16 December 1993. That motion would require publication by way of tabling in parliament of departmental file titles relating to policy matters, legislation and the like.

That was the undertaking of the minister. Then, I understand—I understand also that it is not in dispute—that consultation took place between Senator Harradine and Senator Evans as to the implementation of that undertaking and they reached agreement as to a set of words. Senator Evans I think has referred to his correspondence dated 27 June in which he put a detailed drafting proposal to Senator Harradine as to how it might be implemented. It covered, as I read it, all departments. It simply provided for the information to be staggered in the future for management purposes.

PARA.TAB: It seems from the correspondence that Senator Harradine, or Senator Harradine's office, agreed to that detail. So basically the Senate was then in a situation where the Leader of the Government in the Senate had given an undertaking to Senator Harradine. He and Senator Harradine had discussed the detailed form of that undertaking, agreement had been reached and it was then in the form of an agreed motion between the two of them to be brought to the Senate.

What then happened was that we said that we believed, notwithstanding that agreement, that there were practical issues that still might be looked at by a Senate committee. You may remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, the contribution of Senator Vanstone on behalf of the coalition on 28 June 1994 when that debate came on in the Senate. I will quote at random from her short speech. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the coalition is very supportive of the intention of Senator Harradine's motion . . . that we are not in any way trying to stop his motion.
She said that we were interested in seeing whether it might be further improved. She went on to say:
We are strongly supportive of any initiatives to improve the accountability of the executive to this parliament.
She said that we wanted to ensure that it was being done in a cost efficient form. She then said that we would be interested to see:
. . . whether the intention of Senator Harradine's motion can be further refined in a more practical and cost-efficient way than it already has been.

Therefore, we moved an amendment to the motion asking that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration look at particular issues within the sentiment of what she expressed. They were issues such as whether the material was being produced in a user friendly form; questions of practicability, how it could be done in a practical way; cost—we are always sensitive to issues of cost; implications for the departments; and, lastly, whether any more efficient and effective method may be devised to achieve the objectives behind the order. In other words, it was not an amendment to the motion to reconsider the substance of the Harradine initiative but rather to see whether it was being implemented in the most effective and efficient way.

PARA.TAB: Regrettably, it seems from our consideration of the subsequent committee report that the committee was somewhat sidetracked, and it seemed largely sidetracked by a government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that Senator Kemp and Senator Campbell were sidetracked?
—It might call for an explanation by the chair; I do not know. It seems that the committee took only one submission and that was from the government, and the government, rather than—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Hill has made an offensive reference to three members of his own party, Senator Kemp, Senator Campbell and Senator Watson, saying that they are incapable of forming a rational view on the matters in issue referred to them by the committee, that they were sidetracked by a government submission. That is manifestly offensive and I ask him to withdraw it.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: absolutely no offence was taken by any of us and I am sure no offence was intended. Perhaps Senator Coates was offended and he may want to defend himself.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: is there a point of order which deals with gross hypocrisy by the Leader of the Government, because that is what we have just heard?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Perhaps we have just heard another one. I think it might be better if Senator Hill continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it you have ruled against the minister, Mr Acting Deputy President. He should not abuse the standing orders in that way. Basically, the committee was, it seems, sidetracked by a submission of the government that sought to get a second bite of the cherry. Rather than start from the premise that agreement had been reached between the minister and Senator Harradine, it really wanted the matters to be reconsidered. That, in effect, goes considerably beyond what we had intended and had implemented through the amendment we made to the motion in this place, which was to look at practical issues of implementation.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line of that was that, notwithstanding the advice of the committee, the coalition had to consider whether the case had been made out to, in effect, revoke the order of the Senate as to the tabling of documents and substitute something that was entirely different, that is, a test case in relation to two particular departments. We were a party to the previous motion that had led to that order, and we do not see, on the substance of the argument, that that case has been made out.

We regret that the government did not go into the committee and acknowledge that the motion that was implemented through an order of this Senate was the agreement that had been reached between Senator Harradine and Senator Evans. If it had started and been debated on that basis, perhaps we would not be here today wanting to unscramble the egg and start again.

On the merit, basically we think the government ought to stand by the undertaking that it gave in this matter. It may not have been our preferred way to do business. Nevertheless, Senator Evans saw it as an opportunity to get himself out of the sports rorts inquiry; he gave certain undertakings; and he then reached agreement on the detail pursuant to his undertakings. And why should he not be made to keep those undertakings? It basically amounts to that. It was a highly convenient argument for him on that late night in the Senate, I can remember, when he was so proud of his efforts in avoiding an inquiry into Senator Richardson—

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't really need to do it.
—Senator Kernot was a party to it as well. She did not want an inquiry into Senator Richardson. Because the Australian Democrats were told to jump, they said, `How high?'
—You had your scalp.

—I can remember Senator Kernot said, `We are not interested in the past; we are only interested in the future. We want accountability for the future as well.' But unless the Australian people want to really know how this government abuses their trust, how it abuses their taxes, we will never get full and proper accountability for the future. That is what it amounts to. We could never understand why, when it gets so close to the mark, the Australian Democrats are not prepared to put the government under final pressure. They did not do it over the Marshall Islands affair, they did not do it under sports rorts, and on both occasions they let their constituency down and the Australian people down.

PARA.TAB: I hope that Senator Kernot will get up here today and say, `At least now I will keep the minister to his undertakings that he gave on that late night in the Senate.' That will be interesting to see. It is amazing that the minister has come in here today and tried to renege on his previous undertakings. We think he ought to stand by them, and therefore we will not support his motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I took offence at Senator Hill's assertion—
—You are always taking offence.
—No, I do not take offence very easily at all, but I do take offence at his suggesting that the committee was sidetracked by the government submission.
—Why didn't you take other submissions? You were the chairman.

—If I can quote paragraph (d), the committee sought information, amongst other things, about `the implications of the order for Commonwealth departments'. The only people that can give that sort of information are the government itself and the Commonwealth departments through a government submission. What we did was to seek an overall government submission rather than to write off to every individual department, for the simplicity of the operation and because of the timescale of the inquiry, which was relatively short.

PARA.TAB: I will concentrate on the issues of principle involved here, because I feel very strongly about them. What Senator Hill in his response concentrated on was issues of administration. He concentrated on the sports grants matters and he said that we have to make sure that the government is accountable. Senator Harradine talked about it all being a matter of audit and control. But Senator Harradine goes further and wants to know about policy development processes.

I guess the reason why the opposition has not concentrated on that is that it has finally decided that it definitely has not a chance of government in the foreseeable future, so it will not be faced with this sort of problem. But I very strongly support open government and I resent the suggestion that, by supporting Senator Evans's motion, one is somehow against open government.

Maybe Senator Harradine needs to have explained the difference between open government and that other phrase that was used in the government submission about `government in the open'. The system that we have involves the development of policy by the government, which then brings legislation to the parliament to see whether the parliament will agree with it. I am not going to get into issues of the powers of the Senate and the House of Representatives and all that sort of thing. That is not the issue. I am happy to talk about the parliament dealing with the government's legislation after it has gone through its processes of developing its policy.

The trouble is that Senator Harradine, while not being part of the government, wants to be part of the government's policy development process. He wants all sorts of clues about what the government is up to in its policy development process. Therefore, he wants the titles of files to help him and others with fishing expeditions about policy development. I guess one could pose the rhetorical question: if he wants the titles of files and if he wants this degree of open government, why does he not just demand all the files? Why bother with any degree of secrecy about the proposals at all? In this issue of policy development—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where would the Senate be without the Greens?

—Do you mind for a change, Senator Kemp, just piping down? In this issue of policy development, there are, I suppose, two aspects. One is policy development by departments putting proposals up to executive government, and the other is the development by the government in general of those policies that it stood for election on, has in its platform, and wants to develop.

PARA.TAB: There are processes that it should be allowed to go through, with the assistance of the Public Service, in developing those policies and getting them through its own systems of caucus committees and caucus. These are not matters which, until they are finally settled by the government, the rest of the parliament should or needs to be involved in. Senator Harradine may regret not being part of those government policy discussions, but he is not part of the government and he should acknowledge that.

I emphasise again that I am not talking about the accountability for administration. That is what Senator Hill concentrated on—and reasonably so. Where there is some question of accountability of government processes of administration there are appropriate questions that can be asked and committee references that can be made. The phrase that Senator Harradine used was `audit and control'; but audit and control is not an issue of policy development. Those are the sorts of files which I do not see it is reasonable to have provided in this totally open way.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the policy advice involved in the types of motions—
—I think those are matters for internal government operation.
—The motion already says that. You agreed that they should meet.
—If it turns out that in the development of policy there is some fraud involved, or whatever, that is an issue of administration that can then be dealt with.
—But in your own document you say—
—That is not my document. The document I support is the committee report to the Senate.
—It is our document; it is the committee's document.

—I was going to come to that. The opposition did agree with it. The key point in it is that a government is entitled to have its departments develop policy advice in confidence, including the stages prior to such advice becoming cabinet documents. It may be that people want to propose changing our entire system of government and having, as some other countries do, parliamentary committees closely involved in the development of government policy, budgets and so on. But we have a system whereby the government comes up with its budget and its policy proposals, introduces its legislation and runs the gamut of the parliament. But to change the system entirely, as is the implication of Senator Harradine's proposal—
—John Dawkins brought parliamentarians in.
—What a particular minister does in relation to an area in order to ensure that legislation gets through is within that minister's—
—Sid helped draft the budget. So did Senator Kernot.

—That is all right but it does not mean the system should be changed to require that. I believe that the government should be able to develop its policies, including through its caucus system, and then introduce the legislation to the parliament—including the Senate. There is no justification for the policy development process up to that point being revealed to Senator Harradine or anybody else.
—So you won't support this motion by Senator Evans today?

—Of course I will support the motion. I am providing a point of view which explains why I supported the committee report and why I believe that on the matter of policy development Senator Harradine is on the wrong track. I am all in favour, as I say, of open government, of parliamentary committees getting help from government departments and of Senator Harradine getting help in performing his duty as a senator. But his duty and responsibility as a senator do not extend to being part of the government's policy development process.

PARA.TAB: The committee, while agreeing with this point about developing policy advice in confidence, said, `Okay, let us have a trial which is a real trial—not involving all 18 departments, or however many we have, but involving two departments—to see the practicalities of providing these file titles.' It was a compromise—even though I do not agree with providing the whole extent of the file titles—to say, `Let us see how is would work in practice, and do it prospectively.' I believe strongly that on administrative matters the parliament has a responsibility to oversee, as does the Auditor-General, to make sure there is proper accountability for the way the government performs. But policy development processes should be a matter for the government until it introduces its legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are all revisiting and rewriting a bit of history, we need to remember some of the facts. It is not a private undertaking between Senator Harradine and Senator Evans; it was by way of a ministerial statement. The one thing I remember about this night is that Senator Evans could have walked away from the chamber without giving us anything, the vote for the committee having been lost. Nevertheless, he did not do that.
—What a nice bloke!

—It is more than some of the people on Senator Kemps's side might do; but we will wait and see. I note the words that were part of that undertaking. They were, `subject to further discussion on detailed drafting,' which then took place. The politics is that executive government did not like what Senator Evans gave away that night and it is now trying to find a compromise. The compromise involves a trial with two departments, qualifications about what are excluded, and prospective application. I do not mind the prospective application because I think that in most things we do, when we change the rules and know we have changed the rules we all know how to organise ourselves to comply with those new rules.
—And how to camouflage.

—All right; and how to camouflage—they probably still do it. The other part of the politics that is a bit fuzzy is the three illustrious members of the opposition. I have been on this finance and public administration committee as a visiting member and I am absolutely amazed that Senator Kemp and Senator Campbell could have been sidetracked, as Senator Hill says. They need to remember who wrote the terms of reference for this committee; it was their own Senator Vanstone. Why were they not paying greater attention; why were they not focussing on what Senator Vanstone was asking them to do on that committee?
—Yes, teacher.
—What was that interjection?
—It was, `Yes, teacher.' It was a very sophisticated interjection.

—Very sophisticated! While we are revisiting this accountability package, Senator Hill needs to be reminded of some of the outcomes of that package which we are already working through in this parliament, not the least of which are the redrafted audit bill, the establishment of a parliamentary audit committee and the improved resourcing of the Office of the Auditor-General. We are not just focussing on the glory of getting a ministerial scalp; we are not focussing on the short term. We are saying to ourselves, `Let's try to make sure, by putting these processes in place, that this does not happen again.' Senator Harradine is attempting to do something a little similar.

PARA.TAB: It is getting a little tiring hearing this `abuse the Democrats' mantra of Senator Hill day after day. He seems to selectively forget the way in which we have cooperated with other Senate committees, including the Senate print media inquiry, the ABC inquiry and others that could be named. But Senator Hill likes to be selective in his mantra and he forgets the way he joins with other minorities to defeat government purposes in this place.

However, having said all that, I have to say that I think the combination of the Spring session dates, which will be amended, and the public interest qualifications which have been added to this motion all sounds a bit too slippery for me. We saw in the debate relating to the print media inquiry the whole argument of public interest immunity. We have seen how far we have been able to take that. We know that we can come to the same dead end in this one, too, I suspect. But, given the Australian Democrats' record on the need for greater accountability of executive government and our involvement in this accountability package, the Democrats cannot come down on this occasion on the side of executive government using the public interest argument yet again.

Senator Hill, though, concluded his remarks by quoting some comments he says I made about being interested in the past or the future. I am particularly interested in the future, to see whether this opposition will use the same arguments about open and accountable government and public interest immunity if it is ever in government. I hope I am around to see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly hope Senator Kernot is around when we are in government because she will see good government. Good government is what this country deserves—not what we are getting at the moment. She will see open government and accountable government, because one of the things we have learned from being in opposition—I have been in it for only a short time and not for as long as some of my friends and colleagues—is that, as Senator Gareth Evans would have learned when he was in opposition, it is very important to strike the right balance between accountability and accountability particularly to the parliament.
—He has mellowed with the benefit of government.

—He has—as Jim Hacker did as well. We in the Senate certainly hope, for the esteem of the Senate, that Senator Evans's career follows that of Jim Hacker, moving from administrative services to the prime ministership. We wish him well, and he may come across even more Sir Humphreys on his trip to the Lodge.

PARA.TAB: A few points need to be made here. Firstly, all of this emanates from the so-called accountability package based, as it was, on a desperate attempt to ensure that there was not a parliamentary, or at least a Senate, inquiry into what became known as the sports rorts affair. Senator Evans, on 3 March, made a number of solemn promises to the Senate. The first part of that package was the new audit act, the parliamentary audit committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all being done.

—It has not all been done yet; it is certainly on the way, and that is very good. And there was to be a single line budget for the Australian National Audit Office. I am not quite sure whether that will be done, but we will certainly see about that. The second part of the accountability package was a review of the Auditor-General's budget in the wake of the Centenary House royal commission undertaken by Justice Morling. We know there was some delay in that report because of the powers that were required to undertake that inquiry, but we now have the Morling report.

PARA.TAB: Although that report may not have come out the way the coalition thought it might, one thing that needs to be remembered by the Senate is that Mr Justice Morling made some comments about the funding of the audit office. He specifically said that there will be a shortfall of just over half a million dollars in the next financial year, rising to a shortfall of $3.6 million towards the end of the lease and a total of $23.3 million during the term of that lease to the Australian Labor Party. So that is $23.3 million under the current funding arrangements that the audit office will be down and $23.3 million the Australian Labor Party will be up. This is mentioned on page 127 of the report entitled Royal commission of inquiry into the leasing by the Commonwealth of accommodation in Centenary House.

The report goes on to say on page 127 that, depending on various assumptions that can be made in the Department of Finance arising from the property index, the shortfall for the audit office could be $35.2 million—that is, a $35.2 million windfall for the Australian Labor Party. That is not the money the Labor Party gets; that is just the windfall—the difference between what the audit office would normally be funded to and what the lease at Centenary House would provide. So we hope that Senator Evans's promise to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to read out the rest of the report?
—I think that would delay the—
—You are pretty selective.

—These are the points that are relevant here. We have always said that, if there were an independent inquiry and if it were conducted properly, we would accept the findings, which is exactly what has happened. I do accept them. I played a major part in ensuring there was an inquiry, and I think it was an inquiry that should have been made. It highlighted a number of very serious flaws in the way the government goes about—
—And you will apologise for all those disgraceful allegations you made in the months leading up to it?

—No, I do not. I made one allegation that I think, with the value of hindsight, I may regret. But there are lots of other allegations that I do not regret. Senator Kemp, as the shadow minister for administrative services, has been instrumental in getting before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration an inquiry into the property dealings by the government.
—Would you go back to your sidetracked status?

—I will, but I keep getting sidetracked by interjections from the former chair of that committee. That was the second point of Senator Evans's undertakings in the so-called accountability package on 3 March, and we are yet to see what the government will do about that. Until we see what financing is put in place for the Auditor-General's activities, a lot of the rest of it is just a joke. We can have a very strong and independent audit office, but if it is $35 million down the can, if the ALP is getting $35 million that the Auditor-General would have been getting, we have a serious problem.

PARA.TAB: The other part of the accountability package is the code of conduct for members and senators. I am not sure of the status of that code of conduct. I think I saw a copy of it this morning at a shadow ministry meeting. If that was the code of conduct, we will see what it will do to improve the conduct of ministers. I do not think—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it improve Richo's behaviour?
—I just wonder whether former Senator Richardson or Mrs Kelly—
—Can you legislate for that?

—I do not think we can, and this parliament chose not to legislate when it came to codifying company directors' conduct. I think we would have the same trouble here, but we will have that debate another day. Again, I am just saying this is a part of the accountability package, so that people understand where we are going.

PARA.TAB: The other part of the package is the register of interests that we have all now filled in. Again, I do not think that would have made one iota of difference to former Senator Richardson, who already had his register of interests, or Mrs Kelly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor the Prime Minister.

—And, as Senator Newman says, the Prime Minister. Of course, the final part of the accountability package is the pledge to implement Senator Harradine's motion No. 544, which was put down on 16 December 1993. That leads us to say we have made an assessment, as I have gone through, as to how far we have got in implementing the accountability package. The audit act stuff was already under way. The Auditor-General's budget is still a matter that has not been put into place, so we will judge that when we see it.
—It hasn't been ignored.

—No, it has not been ignored. We have had the Morling inquiry, and we will find out in the next few weeks what will happen to the Auditor-General's budget. That is a crucial thing. We will see. Let us just go one bit at a time. The parliament will discuss the new audit act in the next few months. The code of conduct and the register of interests I have already referred to. They are both matters that go to the accountability of everyone else except the executive government. Then we come to Senator Harradine's motion. With respect to almost all planks of the accountability package, either they are irrelevant or the government has walked away from them. In relation to Senator Harradine's motion, we have certainly seen the government try to—
—What did you say? All planks are irrelevant?

—No, a number of them are irrelevant and the others are yet to be put in place and may not be—it will depend when they get put in place. Finally, we have Senator Harradine's motion, which is the subject of this debate and which I will now get to. I want to go to the particular point about our committee's handling of it. Senator Evans wants to say that we have been sidetracked or that we were not being consistent. There is only one person who has not been consistent here, and that is Senator Evans. Not only did he make a specific promise on 3 March to implement, after further discussion, Senator Harradine's motion No. 544, but the government went through, as has been described ad nauseam, a process of negotiation with Senator Harradine to ensure that the motion was put into a format that clearly Senator Evans and the government that he represents would be happy with.

PARA.TAB: Negotiations took place between Senator Harradine and Senator Evans. The fact that a final agreement had been reached was not put in the government's submission to our committee. TALK.START.PARA: —It was.

—If it was, it was not in our report and it certainly is not in the government's submission. Nowhere does it say, `This is the final position that the government has agreed to.' It may not have been representative of the government's view.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the government's submission we would clearly think that Senator Evans pleaded with Senator Harradine to make some amendments; but if we look at the submission from the government on or about the same day, clearly Senator Evans's position was not the government's position. Senator Evans is in the uncomfortable position of facing enormous pressure from within his government to get out of this. That is the real problem. That minister signs off with Senator Harradine on what he can deliver. It is not within a few weeks, but after six months, that we are told that is impractical to implement. TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—There has been a number of extraordinary features about this debate. They were simply sidetracked, says Senator Hill, by virtue of the government submission on this particular matter—a government submission that squarely addressed the very issues that the committee was set up to review.

PARA.TAB: The second most extraordinary thing about this debate has been the performance we have just witnessed from the two sidetrackees, who showed their absolute inability to be frank with the Senate by the way in which they ducked, weaved, shifted and diverted their way through their contributions to this debate—doing everything in this Senate except explaining why it is they are now turning 180 degrees on the matters in issue from the positions they adopted when they were sitting on that committee and responding to the issues before that committee. They have done everything today except explain why it is they voted, as members of the committee, explicitly for a recommendation to revoke the order of June 1994 and are now, in the Senate, voting to reinstate and to maintain that particular order.

They have done everything except address the issues that this particular committee was set up to address and which they addressed, presumably with a degree of persistence and attention to the policy issues involved, which presumably they addressed, in terms of the outcome, with a degree of policy decency because they responded, as committee members, to the concerns expressed by the government about the unworkability of this particular measure with a bit of decency and with a bit of regard to the realities of government administration and the practical difficulties of making a resolution like this work, but they showed themselves utterly unable to sustain that decency for more than about five minutes when they got a sniff of some politics involved in the way in which this matter has come before the parliament. They ought to be ashamed of themselves. For them to say that they were undertaking their committee responsibilities in a sense of ignorance or of being unaware of the nature of the course of events that had preceded the establishment of the committee is to either dissimulate or to carry ignorance to the point of unbelievable ineptitude.

The truth of the matter was that it was perfectly evident that the particular resolution passed in June was one that the government was prepared to accept in the very terms in which Senator Harradine moved it. It was clear from my statement in March that there were going to be discussions about the drafting of the terms of that resolution. It was perfectly clear from what Senator Harradine said in the Senate. As reported on page 2100 of the Senate Hansard of 28 June, in moving and amending his own motion, Senator Harradine said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans on that day—
he is referring to 3 March—
gave that assurance, subject to further consideration and details, to ensure that it was properly implemented. Further discussions have taken place. The result is the motion I have now moved.
There is Harradine on the record saying that the results of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine!

—Senator Harradine saying, `The result of the discussions is the motion I now move—it is the product of discussions.' Of course, it was the subject of discussions and, of course, I frankly acknowledge that I was party to those discussions and conceded. The reason I conceded is that I was over a barrel. Senator Harradine had a majority in this place and I had made a commitment to do something in that area. He took a position. I went as far as I could go in accommodating him and that is the basis of it. There is no doubt and there is no mystery about all of that.

Let Senator Vanstone speak for herself. Let me quote these two paragraphs on page 2103 of the Hansard of 28 June. This is the Senator Vanstone who actually moved the motion to refer this to the committee and who moved the precise terms of reference—all the terms of reference—that the committee adopted. Senator Vanstone said:

SPEECH.PARA: So just providing the information in form is not good enough. We think this is a good enough idea to ensure that the information is provided in a user-friendly form. Some of the other things we want to look at are:
the practicality of implementing the order;
the cost of carrying out the order;
the implications of the order for Commonwealth Departments;—
This is still Senator Vanstone—the opposition's Senator Vanstone who moved the motion and who set the terms of reference, and I quote again:

We also need to look at whether there is another more efficient and effective way to achieve the same aim. So we are not in any way opposed to the intent of what Senator Harradine wants to achieve. We are strongly supportive of any initiatives to improve the accountability of the executive to this parliament. We just want to make the point that for ideals to become reality, a lot of hard work has to take place. Someone has to have an idea.

For once, that was a perfectly sensible proposition from Senator Vanstone about the need to scrutinise again the whole substance of this particular resolution. She was obviously concerned that this might not be the most practical, cost-effective and reasonable way of advancing an aim, or an aspiration or an intention which we were all prepared to share. So that is the basis on which opposition senators embarked upon this exercise. They did it with their eyes open. They showed a bit of policy decency for once in the way in which they responded to the committee obligation. They have run out of decency pretty rapidly as soon as the opportunity has now come to test their consistency and seriousness of purpose in this matter. That will be remembered by most people whom they would like to take them seriously.

PARA.TAB: The final point that I want to make is about the workability of the order in the present form. The only real exemptions in the way in which that order is expressed at the moment are for these three specific areas in relation to titles which would necessarily disclose commercially confidential, identifiably personal or national security matters.

As a practical matter of executive government, there are many more kinds of disclosure than those subsumed by just those three categories which would create real practical difficulties for the business of government. Take economic management, for example; take exchange rate management; take the possibility of a new tax measure or a new savings measure with very substantial implications for a particular affected group which the government is at an early stage of considering—matters which, in the time-honoured business of government, all sides of politics have acknowledged to be matters that are entirely appropriately maintained confidential until such time as the government is ready to make the announcement and then to bear the consequences, bear the flack, of the decision for better or for worse.

Take in my own foreign policy area the number of issues that might well be disclosed by file titles that were other than purely anodyne and purely useless. They might disclose the possibility of a particular visit by some statesman, a head of government or someone from another country which would be highly sensitive and very damaging to our bilateral relations with that government were the terms of it to be disclosed before it was ready to be announced in that other country. That has nothing to do with personal confidentiality. That has nothing to do with national security, because national security does not mean just foreign relations at large. National security means things going to the defence and security of the country.

Let us instance an important international matter, but not one immediately related to the defence of the integrity of the country—for example, a Security Council candidacy, or a policy initiative that we might be imminently about to launch in relation to some matter of United Nations administration, or perhaps the composition of the Security Council. They may be highly sensitive matters that one does not want perhaps to let out that one is even considering because to do so would be counterproductive to the ends one is trying to achieve. Questions of support for particular candidacies and questions about aspects of one's bilateral relations and a possible shift in policy in relation to some other country—issues of this kind traditionally have been regarded as sufficiently sensitive to justify not only confidentiality as to the detail, because the detail will not be revealed by this, but confidentiality as to whether or not the government is actually in the business of giving consideration to the matter at all.

These are the things that we are genuinely concerned about in the motion as it is at the moment. Maybe I was not sufficiently focused on them or concerned about them in the rush of events back in June to have focused on the implications of them and to have had discussions in the way that in retrospect I should have. But that focus has been placed upon these sorts of issues, and many others as well, in the government's submission and it was the subject of the committee consideration during that period.

It is a fruitless task, given the way in which people have now committed themselves and the way in which they are obviously going to vote, to get them to go backwards on this. But I do ask that there be a willingness to look at the implications of this in practice sooner rather than later. If this thing is going to be passed, let us not only do it with the date amendments which Senator Harradine has kindly indicated he is willing to accept—that is helpful and I thank him; and we will certainly embrace those—but let us do it with some earlier review mechanism than that which was originally contemplated after the two-year period.

I foreshadow that I will so move if it can be done, hopefully by leave; otherwise I will have to put a notice of motion in—and I do not want to debate this all over again. But I would ask, if it is possible to reach consensus on this proposition, that a review be undertaken by the Finance and Public Administration References Committee of the information provided in response to paragraphs (a) and (b) of the amended motion, the committee to report to the Senate by no later than 30 June 1995.

I would ask the opposition, for all the rest of the absence of help it has given us, at least to contemplate the utility of having some earlier review mechanism in place, given what opposition senators themselves have put their signatures to, namely, a serious expression of concern as to the cost effectiveness and workability of the particular thing that they are now about to ram down our throats.

Rather than leave it a couple of years, as was originally contemplated—and I frankly acknowledge that it was contemplated it would be a couple of years—let us please have a look at it on the basis of the first two batches of information that will be laboriously compiled and will be put down, using our best endeavours, in February and March in compliance, I hope, with the terms of this motion.

I would ask Senator Harradine—I know he is a bit grumpily inclined about this particular proposal—to perhaps reconsider that opposition and perhaps be prepared in good faith to accept the legitimacy of our concerns about just whether this is going to work or not. When he sees what he gets in February and March he might be the first person shrieking for a review, saying, `This is no good. This is not telling me anything.' That is a possibility. It will not be for an absence of good faith; but it may just be the nature of the exercise that he is demanding of us.

I repeat: the government's position is one of wanting to insist on this particular motion but acknowledging, unhappily, the reality that we are not going to get it, given what has been said, and foreshadowing that further amendment to the original order as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address once again, as I have done over the years, the position of Ellenbrae Station in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. Ellenbrae Station is located in the heart of the Kimberleys. It is accessed by the Gibb River Road, which runs from the Great Northern Highway in the east, joining the Wyndham-Kununurra Road, which runs to Derby in the west. The station is surrounded predominantly by other pastoral leases, except to the north and west, where Drysdale River National Park is situated. To the east of that, there is the Oombulguri Reserve, which was formerly the Forrest River Mission. As I have said in this place before, in 1990 the first big fire came out of Oombulguri and burnt 80 per cent of Ellenbrae Station. To my knowledge, since then it has been burnt out from that same direction for four out of the last five years, putting Ellenbrae in an impossible situation.

PARA.TAB: I asked during estimates and in this place about the position of Aboriginal reserves. I asked whether they have insurance cover—as is the case with any other incorporated organisations or individual organisations which carry on some sort of commercial or cultural activity and which have insurance to cover damage caused by that pastoral lease, farming entity or whatever—with regard to actions they have undertaken which involve water or fire escaping from that property. I could never get an answer as to what the situation might be—especially from Senator Cook, who at the time was handling questions in the Senate relating to that portfolio.

It is not compulsory to have this sort of third party insurance, but of course it is wise to do so in case, say, a fire goes from my property on to somewhere else and burns the neighbours out. I was never able, as I said, to get any answer on the situation. The owners of Ellenbrae Station have not been able to get any compensation out of anyone in all that time.

During the debate on the Mabo legislation last year, Senator Gareth Evans, who led the debate on the bill for the government, assured us that all regulations on such things as bushfires and land care would apply to land held by Aboriginals in their own names or land secured by this Mabo style legislation where native title existed. We were led to believe that that was the situation but, of course, now the owner of this station, Byrne Terry, has nowhere to go except to start some impossible sort of action. If there had been insurance, they would have had some recourse, but obviously they do not.

I do not know where these people can go because, at any drop of a hat, they could get the same treatment. From certain investigations that have been done, we have found out that the attitude of the Aboriginal community and, for that matter, the attitude of the government department responsible for Aboriginal affairs in Western Australia—I wish Senator Collins would visit the place and get his own view on the impossible position that these people are in—towards the land-holders is unacceptable.

It appears the rights of land-holders are secondary to the rights of the Aboriginal community. That may be so. If they want to think that way, let them think that way. But to take out common third party insurance would be a very wise idea. The people are still legitimately in pastoral pursuits. I say `legitimately' because anyone running a pastoral concern is legitimate when they pay their pastoral fees, adhere to what the pastoral board of Western Australia tells them to do and pay their fees for shire rates and pay their land lease rates to the West Australian government. So they should have some rights in this situation. Clearly, this sort of discrimination affects other people besides the Terrys of Ellenbrae station.

As I have already said, the present situation in light of the Mabo decision has given rise to conflict between Aborigines and other residents of this country. Until responsible and reasonable safeguards are put in place, this problem will continue—and it is very interesting to note that the minister with responsibility for Aboriginal matters in this chamber has just walked out without listening. Until reasonable and responsible safeguards are put in place, this problem will continue to manifest itself, creating division between the Aboriginal community and other land-holders. Senator Evans told us time and time again during the Mabo debate last year that that would not happen.

It appears clear that if the fire had escaped from leasehold property—that is, another sort of pastoral lease, under which the majority of land in that area is—the owners of the station would have been compensated through the insurance that they would have held. Through no fault of their own, the owners of Ellenbrae have suffered extreme hardship, which will continue unless the problem is addressed immediately. The attitude displayed by government departments which handle Aboriginal affairs is clearly biased and dismissive of any problems as far as the Aboriginal community is concerned. This is quite contrary to the actual position that prevails.

In summary, the situation is that this station that operates as a legal pastoral entity has been burnt out four times in the last five years. The year I flew over it, it was completely burnt out. The cattle holding, according to the best figures that I have, has been reduced from about 20,000 to about 2,000 or 3,000 because of these fires—deliberately lit in most cases, as far as I can see—which have driven them almost to the point of bankruptcy. The owners of Ellenbrae have had to take on other jobs, such as operating bulldozers for the shire and doing contract work for the shire, to keep their station going. They have dug in and said that they are not going to be driven out by fires. Yet federal departments are not interested in the problem, nor is the Aboriginal department interested in the problem.

For the sake of justice, it is time that someone took this matter in hand and did something about it. Otherwise where is freedom in the Kimberleys, or in Australia for that matter? If the government wants to do away with a pastoral industry in the Kimberleys, or if the Aborigines want to do that, let them say so and properly compensate the people.

I do not believe that is the way to go. We have a viable industry there and we should keep it there. But we should not let the government or anyone else drive these people out by simply burning them out and putting them into bankruptcy. I hope someone takes notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight somewhat disillusioned with what I believe to be the normal processes that should operate under Commonwealth-state relations and responsibilities in regard to environmental management. Many senators will be aware that for a number of months now Senator Woodley, Senator Faulkner, Senator Kernot, Senator Coulter, Senator Ian Macdonald and I have been raising questions about the nature of a major resort development at Oyster Point in the Hinchinbrook area just out of Cardwell. This area, of course, is sandwiched between two unique world heritage areas—the wet tropics and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

PARA.TAB: There have been ongoing strenuous efforts on the part of the Friends of Hinchinbrook. There have been strenuous efforts on the part of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to reach some rational, realistic agreement about the scale and type of development that is appropriate in this very unique area, unique not just for Queenslanders or for Australians but unique by virtue of it being an area between two World Heritage designated areas. I have to say it has been a story of frustration, it has been a story of a refusal of the Queensland department of environment to really come to terms with the nature of its responsibilities as a joint manager with the Commonwealth.

We hear a lot about states rights in this place and in the other place. We hear a lot about the need for cooperation. We hear a lot about the Commonwealth using its powers to override the states. I do not believe that any of that would be necessary if only we could get rational cooperation and coordination. This project got off on the wrong foot to start with when the office of the Coordinator-General decided that it seemed like a good idea at the time to allow a major resort, a very large scale resort, to be developed at this particular location.

Had appropriate environmental impact assessment been undertaken, had there been a genuine consultation and listening to the views, not just of local people but of the scientists who have the understanding of this very special and unique ecosystem, we might not be in the situation that we are today. Perhaps Senator Woodley should have gone first this evening, because I know he will be speaking more about some of these details.

I spent quite a bit of the weekend taking phone calls from the site where people were determined to protect the mangroves. Many senators will say, `Oh, they are protesters; oh, they are radicals, rent-a-crowds.' They are people who are trying to save a relatively small area of mangroves. In this day and age, protection of mangroves, I thought, was pretty well recognised as important, particularly in the vicinity of World Heritage areas. These people are so determined to protect the mangroves. Why do they want to protect mangroves? Why would they sit in mud and walk back and forth through mud for days at a time to protect the mangroves if they did not seriously believe, as the scientists believe, that the mangroves must be protected in order to maintain the existing seagrass beds on which dugong are so dependent?

Let me just draw the Senate's attention to the fact that there has been an overwhelming body of scientific evidence critical of this particular proposal and calling for a much more cautious approach. There has been the Valentine report; three eminent scientists on the ABC's Green and Practical program voiced their concerns last week; and Dr Tony Preen has indicated that mortality rates of dugongs—I remind the Senate, an endangered species—would be likely to rise by 25 per cent in the area as a result of the development.

Perhaps some listeners might say, `Well, this development is on private land. In this country, people have the right to develop on private land providing they go through the proper processes and get the appropriate permits.' I have to say that Keith Williams has those, but the question is: why at this 11th hour on Friday was public land rapidly gazetted so that Keith Williams was able to go in this morning and start removing the mangroves? Why?

Let me describe to the chamber where this resort will be. The resort on land will be, I am sure, an attractive resort. I would say it is far too big. What is on the land is not acceptable in my book, but we are not going to argue about the private land aspect of this. Mr Williams was given permission to put up a fence to protect his site, allegedly from protesters. The only thing is that the protesters have not been on private land; their attention has been towards the mangroves. So the fence went up over the weekend.

There is this absolute determination to remove the mangroves, even though the private land site needs a great deal of attention and work for months before there can be any resort there. But why does Keith Williams want to clear the mangroves? I will tell the Senate why, and some senators will laugh. He wants an artificial Hawaiian style beach there. Why? Because there is no beach there—it is just mud and mangroves—and those senators who know what mangroves are would know that people would not sit on the edge of mangroves to sun themselves.

There is another reason why people would not sit on either the mangrove site or indeed the artificial beach and that is that this particular channel area is infested with crocodiles. The ridiculous thing about this whole development is that people in Brisbane are making decisions and they do not seem to know that they are trying to put a beach along a channel that is infested with crocodiles. Who is going to sit on the beach, much less go into the water, when it is infested with crocodiles?

Just this afternoon I received this note from the partner of a fisherman. He said, `I don't know why anyone would want to put a beach there. There are crocodiles in that channel. It is very unsafe. By the time you get the stingers and the massive crocodiles that come around the protected fish area, why would anybody want to sun themselves on the beach?' The issue here is: why would a government—a government of which I am very proud, the Queensland Labor government—go out of its way to have the mangroves cleared when there is all this work to be done on private land? It just does not make sense. Quite clearly, it is a classic case of people not understanding the issue, making decisions a thousand kilometres or more south and not seeing the reality of their decision making.

What has happened today? The protesters have continued to take the stand, and I commend the stand that they are taking. They are not radical activists; they are very deeply committed people who believe in what they are doing. This morning the excavator moved in. There was no workplace health and safety officer as there should have been. The machine came very close to a number of the protesters. One woman was assaulted and she claims—and I have written it down—that a police officer jabbed her behind the ear; he got a finger near the nerve centre and she temporarily blacked out, and she has had a headache ever since. Another protester was seriously hurt. He was punched, this time not by police—

TALK.START.PARA: —Weren't they trespassing?
—No, he was not trespassing. That is the whole point. Until Friday, this was public land and I think that is where we have to ask many questions about the nature of this development.(Time expired)

—Last Saturday evening I was honoured to meet with President Eduardo Frei of Chile on his visit to Australia en route to the APEC meeting in Bogor, Indonesia. President Frei happily chose to meet with the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Keating, on Saturday and then in the evening to meet with chief executive officers of major Australian enterprises with interests in Chile, and I was one member of the parliament to also meet with him.As president of the Australia-Chile friendship group in this parliament, I was delighted to do so. I am also pleased to see that my only predecessor in that position, Senator Schacht, is present in the chamber. Last parliament a number of us formed the Australia-Chile friendship group. Senator Schacht was a distinguished first president of the group, and I have followed on during this parliament.

PARA.TAB: President Frei brought with him to Australia and on to the Bogor meeting the most powerful delegation of business and parliamentary leaders ever to travel outside Chile with the President. There were six members of parliament and 44 business representatives from Chile who, as chief executive officers, represent enterprises in that country that produce more than half the gross national product of Chile.

Not only did a few of us have the chance to meet with President Frei on Saturday evening, but afterwards there was a very appropriate welcoming dinner for about 100 business representatives and parliamentary representatives who had travelled with the President. This welcoming dinner was sponsored by the Australian-Latin American Business Council, in particular the President, Mr Jose Blanco, who also gave an excellent address at Saturday evening's dinner, also by the Australia-Chile Business and Investment Council and the Australia-Chile Chamber of Commerce.

It is significant that in this week, when Chile is admitted for the first time as the newest member of APEC, President Frei chose to stop over in Australia. This visit reinforces the common purpose that Australia and Chile have in working to achieve trade liberalisation in our Asia-Pacific region and in the world at large. As we all know, Chile was a major partner with us in the Cairns Group in the Uruguay Round of the GATT and will continue, I believe, to share many of our objectives in the new World Trade Organisation to begin on 1 January next year. More than that, Australia provides Chile with an opportunity for investment. Chile will be able to establish regional offices in Australia as a doorway into Asia. In a very parallel way, Chile is offering Australia a secure investment base and a place for representative offices, not only for Australian business to take up opportunities in that country, but as a doorway to South America generally.

Currently, Australian trade with Chile is only $140 million but it has grown at the most rapid rate of any country with which Australia has traded over the last 10 years. The average growth for each of the last 10 years has been 35 per cent. I believe that, whilst the whole of our Latin American trade is only one per cent of our exports, it has the prospect of growing three-fold in the next six or seven years. It is with that in mind that I have spoken about Latin America—and Chile and Mexico in particular—as our most prospective business partners, nation to nation, in that region.

Asia—in particular north-east Asia—will be the priority area for Australian exports, but it is right that we look at our newest APEC member as part of a continent that currently receives one per cent of Australian exports; and could receive three times that amount. Australia has $700 million of investments in Chile. In fact, we are the second largest overseas investing nation in that country. A great part of that investment is in the mining industry in Chile which, of course, is the biggest wealth producer for that country. Australian expertise and equipment, and mineral finance—as my colleague Senator Parer understands very well—are areas where Australia can bring investment, technical knowledge and other expertise to Chile to the benefit of both Australia and that country.

I not only note the welcome we all give to President Frei in his timely visit to this country, but also want to note that this has other areas of significance beyond reinforcement of its entry into APEC. President Frei's visit is just 12 months after the visit by President Patricio Aylwin, his predecessor as President of Chile. Former President Aylwin had a successful visit to this country, in particular to the parliament here in Canberra where we welcomed him. To have two presidents in succession—in the space of 12 months—coming from Chile is a very accurate reflection of the importance Chile gives to Australia. We should be much readier to respond to the interest Chile is expressing in Australia.

I urge the Australian government to take up three proposals that I have urged in recent months—and which the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, has happily conversed with me about. We have exchanged letters but it has yet to be fully agreed to. These three proposals are, first, that we establish a bilateral free trade and investment agreement between Australia and Chile, to the benefit of both our countries. I have said in the past that it is not enough for us to get Australia's interests preserved regionally within GATT or the new World Trade Organisation—that is internationally or in APEC. We should have some specific bilateral agreements that are to our benefit and that are WTO and APEC consistent. We ought now to formulate such a bilateral agreement and reinforce all of our opportunities by putting it in place in the coming months.

The second point is that we establish an air link between Lan Chile and Qantas. That is of enormous importance. The third point is that, whether through the east-Asia analytical unit within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or through a similar unit, there should be a detailed economic study of our trade and investment prospects to reinforce all that is happening now. For instance, some 30 firms have their regional offices in Santiago, the capital of Chile. I would like the government to very constructively take up these three proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, protesters were removed from the Oyster Point site near Cardwell in North Queensland. Apparently, they were dragged off by security guards with the coastguard and police looking on. I have been told that protesters on the site were dragged off over and over again. At least two were injured; one was punched unconscious. I am informed that the doctor in Cardwell, not wanting to get involved, refused to treat one of the injured people who had been assaulted by a police officer.

PARA.TAB: Margaret Thorsborne, a 70-year-old lady about five feet tall, was dragged off the site with undue force. I might add that two years ago Margaret Thorsborne was declared to be the citizen of the year in Cardwell. What crime had these people committed? None! There were no arrests. The police were just another service provided by the Queensland government to this developer. What the protesters were doing was a service to all of us in Queensland, Australia and internationally. They were trying to protect our world heritage. That is something the Queensland government and the federal government are charged with doing. However, they have done anything but protect our heritage in this case.

The protesters feel totally disempowered. One of the conservationists just called one of my staff and said, `What do you do? The SES sat under a tarp all day eating pies. This wasn't a show but they turned it into one. What do you do when the people you normally turn to for help, like the coastguard, just watch as someone is knocked unconscious and a gracious and wonderful lady is dragged away? What do you do when the police are knocking people about or turning their backs while someone else does?'

Today in the Senate I gave notice of a motion condemning the Queensland government for its outrageous behaviour in gazetting a piece of public land for the exclusive use of developer Keith Williams. This public land is now a marine park, rather like a national park, and should not be given willy-nilly for destruction by a 24-hour sneaky gazettal. The protesters were trying to protect the old-growth mangroves, which in turn protect the vast seagrass meadows which feed the vulnerable-to-extinction dugong. Those seagrass meadows have been found by internationally recognised marine biologist Tony Preen to have a rare species of seagrass.

In fact, the Hinchinbrook Channel is a place with a number of rare and endangered species. That is why it is World Heritage. That is why it is of paramount importance to protect it. Hinchinbrook was called the jewel in the crown of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park when it was nominated for World Heritage. It was called that because it had nearly all the species of mangroves in Australia; three species of endangered sea turtle—the loggerhead, flatback and green turtle; three species of endangered dolphins—the humpback, bottlenose and irrawaddi; and, of course, the dugong.

There is an area of land near the resort on which Mr Williams wants to build an airport capable of taking 737s. At the moment there is a tiny airstrip adjacent to the Edmund Kennedy national park. Will the Queensland government resume part of the Edmund Kennedy national park for this developer to build his international airport? This tiny strip is at present capable of taking only six-seater aircraft. On the other side, there is the Bruce Highway. I assume even the Queensland government would not gazette that, but who knows? If it makes a present of part of the Edmund Kennedy national park for Mr Williams, perhaps we should say goodbye to the two most endangered mammals in Queensland—that is, the mahogony glider and the cassowary.

In the future, developers such as Mr Williams will never admit that they were responsible for the death of a species. They promise us the world with jobs and income. But, really, does this resort, built on a huge mudflat where people will have to walk hundreds of metres over mud, swatting sandflies, in order to get to water that is a milky colour and very shallow, make any economic sense? The amazing thing is that the Queensland government has swallowed this snake oil sold it by the developer and is bending over backwards to help him.

I have told the parliament before how the Queensland government is selling the heritage of the planet by forcing through this development. This is despite public outcry, outrage from scientists all over the country and overseas, and the reservations of the federal government. One must ask: why support such an appalling plan? I understand the answer is

SPEECH.PARA: that a deal has been done to secure the endorsement of one of the Premier's own AWU faction. So a political deal in Queensland means we will lose our integrity and our gift to future generations.

PARA.TAB: By lunchtime tomorrow, if the federal government does not act to protect these magnificent old-growth mangroves, they will be cleared forever. I call for a moratorium on the clearing, and for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the federal government to act as a matter of urgency to proclaim the Hinchinbrook Channel under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. It is clearly in danger, and we cannot wait until those critically important mangroves are destroyed and the seagrass beds start to die. No-one has a mandate to destroy the earth, but the Queensland government has bent over backwards to give a developer the legal right, but not the moral right, to destroy this part of the earth.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 12 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What progress has the Government made in fulfilling the requirements of the National Program of Action in response to the World Summit for Children.

(2) What specific action has the Minister taken to ensure that the amount of funding allocated to the areas of primary education expenditure and clean water supply in Australia's aid budget is increased in accordance with the recommendations of the report Our Child Our Future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia lodged its National Program of Action, Our Children, Our Future with the United Nations on 22 April 1994. The National Program of Action identified ten key challenges which form a broad framework for action within which governments, the community, families and children themselves can work together to develop improved longer-term policies and programs. The Program of Action commits Australia to meeting the goals of the Declaration by the year 2000.

The World Declaration requests the Secretary-General of the United Nations to arrange for a mid-decade review of progress made towards implementing the commitments of the Declaration and its Plan of Action.

The Commonwealth Government is committed to undertaking consultations with State and Territory governments, and community agencies, as part of the preparation for Australia's mid-term report to the United Nations on our implementation of the National Program of Action. These consultations will begin in 1995.

The mid-term review will present a detailed picture of how Australia has been meeting its commitments under the World Declaration. The Commonwealth's response to these challenges will be fully documented in that review.

To provide a detailed response at present would involve extensive liaison with Government Departments and Agencies, and other Government funded organisations. To provide these details would not only take significant time and resources but would also duplicate the process that will begin in 1995 leading up to the mid-term report to the United Nations.

(2) Since the World Summit for Children in 1990 the Commonwealth's total aid expenditure on primary and secondary education activities has increased significantly, in line with Summit recommendations. In 1991-92 aid expenditure totalled $15.9m. This increased to $18.3m in the last financial year.

Australia's development assistance to water supply activities has increased markedly over the same period. In 1991-92 development assistance to water supply activities totalled $5.4m. This has grown to $23.7m in the 1993-94 financial year.

The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau is currently undertaking a review of the Commonwealth Government's assistance in the education sector with the object of identifying unmet needs in various countries, especially in Asia and the Pacific. The review will focus attention on a range of issues, with particular attention being paid to the educational needs of girls and women.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
